The&longs;e Rules
relate to Towers that are plain and &longs;imple:
But &longs;ome Architects, about half Way of the
Height of the Tower, have adorned it with a
Kind of Portico with in&longs;ulate Columns, others
have made the&longs;e Porticoes &longs;piral all the Way
up, others have &longs;urrounded it with &longs;everal Por­
ticoes like &longs;o many Coronets, and &longs;ome have
covered the whole Tower with Figures of Ani­
mals.

The Rules for the&longs;e Colonades are not
different from tho&longs;e for publick Edifices; only
that we may be allowed to be rather more
&longs;lender in all the Members, upon Account of
the Weight of the Building.

But whoever
would erect a Tower be&longs;t fitted for re&longs;i&longs;ting
the Injuries of Age, and at the &longs;ame Time ex­
tremely delightful to behold, let him upon a
&longs;quare Ba&longs;is, rai&longs;e a round Super&longs;tructure, and
over that another &longs;quare one, and &longs;o on, ma­
king the Work le&longs;s and le&longs;s by Degrees, ac­
cording to the Proportions ob&longs;erved in Co­
lumns.

I will here de&longs;cribe one which I think
well worthy Imitation.

Fir&longs;t from a &longs;quare
Plat&longs;orm ri&longs;es a Ba&longs;ement in Height one tenth
Part of the whole Structure, and in Breadth
one fourth Part of that whole Height.

Again&longs;t
this Ba&longs;ement, in the Middle of each Front
&longs;tand two Columns, and one at each Angle,
di&longs;tingui&longs;hed by their &longs;everal Ornaments, in the
&longs;ame Manner as we ju&longs;t now appointed for Se­
pulchres.

Over this Ba&longs;ement we rai&longs;e a &longs;quare
Super&longs;tructure like a little Chapel, in Breadth
twice the Height of the Ba&longs;ement, and as high
as broad, again&longs;t which, we may &longs;et three,
four or five Orders of Columns, in the &longs;ame
Manner as in Temples.

Over this, we make
our Rotondas, which may even be three in
Number, and which from the Similitude of
the &longs;everal Shoots in a Cane or Ru&longs;h, we &longs;hall
call the Joints.

The Height of each of the&longs;e
Joints &longs;hall be equal to its Breadth, with the
Addition of one twelfth Part of that Breadth,
which twelfth Part &longs;hall &longs;erve as a Ba&longs;ement
to each Joint.

The Breadth &longs;hall be taken
from that &longs;quare Chapel which we placed up­
on the fir&longs;t Ba&longs;ement, in the following Man­
ner: Dividing the Front of that &longs;quare Chapel
into twelve Parts, give eleven of tho&longs;e Parts to
the fir&longs;t Joint; then dividing the Diameter of
this fir&longs;t Joint into twelve Parts, give eleven of
them to the &longs;econd Joint, and &longs;o make the
third Joint a twelfth Part narrower than the
&longs;econd, and thus the &longs;everal Joints will have
the Beauty which the be&longs;t ancient Architects
highly commended in Columns, namely, that
the lower Part of the Shaft &longs;hould be one &longs;ourth
Part thicker than the upper.

Round the&longs;e
Joints we mu&longs;t rai&longs;e Columns with their proper
Ornaments, in Number not le&longs;s than eight, nor
more than &longs;ix: Moreover, in each Joint, as al­
&longs;o in the &longs;quare Chapel, we mu&longs;t open Lights
in convenient Places, and Niches with the Or­
naments &longs;uitable to them.

The Lights mu&longs;t
not take up above half the Aperture between
Column and Column.

The &longs;ixth Story in this
Tower, which ri&longs;es from the third Rotonda
mu&longs;t be a &longs;quare Structure, and its Breadth and
Height mu&longs;t not be allowed above two third
Parts of that third Rotonda.

Its Ornament
mu&longs;t be only &longs;quare Pila&longs;ters &longs;et again&longs;t the
Wall, with Arches turned over them, with
their proper Dre&longs;s of Capitals, Architraves and
the like, and between Pila&longs;ter and Pila&longs;ter, half
the Break may be le&longs;t open for Pa&longs;&longs;age.

The
&longs;eventh and la&longs;t Story &longs;hall be a circular Por­
tico of in&longs;ulate Columns, open for Pa&longs;&longs;age
every Way; the Length of the&longs;e Columns, with
their Intablature, &longs;hall be equal to the Diame­
ter of this Portico it&longs;elf, and that Diameter
&longs;hall be three fourths of the &longs;quare Building,
on which it &longs;tands.

This circular Portico &longs;hall
be covered with a Cupola.

Upon the Angles
of the &longs;quare Stories in the&longs;e Towers we &longs;hould
&longs;et Acroteria equal in Height to the Archi­
trave, Freze and Cornice which are beneath
them.

In the lowermo&longs;t &longs;quare Story, placed
ju&longs;t above the Ba&longs;ement, the open Area within
may be five eighths of the outward Breadth.

Among the ancient Works of this Nature, I
am extremely well plea&longs;ed with Ptolomey's
Tower in the I&longs;land of Pharos, on the Top of
which, for the Direction of Mariners, he placed
large Fires, which were hung in a continual
Vibration, and kept always moving about from
Place to Place, le&longs;t at a Di&longs;tance tho&longs;e Fires
&longs;hould be mi&longs;taken for Stars; to which he ad­
ded moveable Images, to &longs;hew from what Cor­
ner the Wind blew with others, to &longs;hew in
what Part of the Heavens the Sun was at that
Time, and the Hour of the Day: Inventions
extremely proper in &longs;uch a Structure.
CHAP. VI.

Of the principle Ways belonging to the City, and the Methods of adorning the
Haven, Gates, Bridges, Arches, Cro&longs;s-ways and Squares.

It is now Time to make our Entrance into
the City; but as there are &longs;ome Ways
both within and without the Town which are
much more eminent than the common Sort,
as tho&longs;e which lead to the Temple, the Ba&longs;i­
lique, or the Place for publick Spectacles, we
&longs;hall fir&longs;t &longs;ay &longs;omething of the&longs;e.

We read
that Heliogabalus paved the&longs;e broader and no­
bler Ways with Macedonian Marble and Por­
phiry.

Hi&longs;torians &longs;ay much in Prai&longs;e of a noble
Street in Buba&longs;tus, a City of Ægypt, which led
to the Temple; for it ran thro' the Market­
place, and was paved with very fine Stone, was
four Jugera, or four hundred and eighty Foot
broad, and bordered on each Side with &longs;tately
Trees. Ari&longs;teas tells us, that in Feru&longs;alem
there were &longs;ome very beautiful Streets, tho'
narrow, thro' which the Magi&longs;trates and Nobles
only were allowed to pa&longs;s, to the Intent chiefly
that the &longs;acred Things which they carried,
might not be polluted by the Touch of any
Thing profane. Plato highly celebrates a Way
all planted with Cypre&longs;s Trees which led from
Gno&longs;&longs;us to the Cave and Temple of Fupiter. I
find that the Romans had two Streets of this
Sort, extremely noble and beautiful, one from
the Gate to the Church of St. Paul, fifteen
Stadia, or a Mile and &longs;even Furlongs in Length,
and the other from the Bridge to the Church
of St. Peter, two thou&longs;and five hundred Foot
long, and all covered with a Portico of Co­
lumns of Marble, with a Roof of Lead.

Such
Ornaments are extremely proper for Ways of
this Nature.

But let us now return to the
more common Highways.

The principal Head
and Boundary of all Highways, whether within
or without the City, unle&longs;s I am mi&longs;taken, is
the Gate for tho&longs;e by Land, and the Haven for
tho&longs;e by Sea: Unle&longs;s we will take notice of
&longs;ubterraneous Ways, of the Nature of tho&longs;e
which we are told were at Thebes in Ægypt,
thro' which their Kings could lead an Army
unknown to any of the Citizens, or tho&longs;e which
I find to have been pretty numerous near Pre­
ne&longs;te, in the ancient Latium, dug under Ground
from the Top of the Hill to the Level of the
Plain, with wonderful Art; in one of which
we are told, that Marius peri&longs;hed when clo&longs;e
pre&longs;&longs;ed by the Siege.

We are told by the
Author of the Life of Apollonius, of a very
wonderful Pa&longs;&longs;age made by a Lady of Media
at Babylon, under the River, and arched with
Stone and Bitumen, thro' which &longs;he could go
dry&longs;hod from the Palace to a Country Hou&longs;e,
on the other Side of the River.

But we are
not obliged to believe all that the Greek Wri­
ters tell us.
To return to our Subject.

The
Gates are adorned in the &longs;ame Manner as tri­
umphal Arches, of which anon.

The Haven
is adorned by broad Porticoes, rai&longs;ed &longs;omewhat
above the Level of the Ground, by a &longs;tately
Temple, lofty and beautiful, with &longs;pacious
Squares before it, and the Mouth of the Ha­
ven it&longs;elf by huge Statues, &longs;uch as were for­
merly to be &longs;een in &longs;everal Places, and particu­
larly at Rhodes, where Herod is &longs;aid to have
erected three.

Hi&longs;torians very much celebrate
the Mole at Samos, which they &longs;ay was an
hundred and twenty Foot high, and ran out
two Furlongs into the Sea.

Doubtle&longs;s &longs;uch
Works mu&longs;t greatly adorn the Haven, e&longs;peci­
ally if they are ma&longs;terly wrought, and not of
ba&longs;e Materials.

The Streets within the City,
be&longs;ides being hand&longs;omely paved and cleanly
kept, will be rendered much more noble, if
the Doors are built all after the &longs;ame Model,
and the Hou&longs;es on each Side &longs;tand in an even
Line, and none higher than another.

The Parts
of the Street which are principally to be ad­
orned, are the&longs;e: The Bridge, the Cro&longs;s-ways,
and the Place for publick Spectactles, which
la&longs;t is nothing el&longs;e but an open Place, with
Seats built about it.

We will begin with the
Bridge, as being one of the chief Parts of the
Street.

The Parts of the Bridge are the Piers,
the Arches and the Pavement, and al&longs;o the
Street in the Middle for the Pa&longs;&longs;age of Cattle,
and the rai&longs;ed Cau&longs;eways on each Side for the
better Sort of Citizens, and the Sides or Rail,
and in &longs;ome Places Hou&longs;es too, as in that mo&longs;t
noble Bridge called Adrian's Mole, a Work
never to be forgotten, the very Skeleton where­
of, if I may &longs;o call it, I can never behold
without a Sort of Reverence and Awe.

It
was covered with a Roof &longs;upported by two­
and-forty Columns of Marble, with their Archi­
trave, Freze and Cornice, the Roof plated with
Bra&longs;s, and richly adorned.

The Bridge mu&longs;t be
made as broad as the Street which leads to it.

The Piers mu&longs;t be equal to one another on
each Side both in Number and Size, and be
one third of the Aperture in Thickne&longs;s.

The
Angles or Heads of the Piers that lie again&longs;t
the Stream mu&longs;t project in Length half the
Breadth of the Bridge, and be built higher than
the Water ever ri&longs;es.

The Heads of the Piers
that lie along with the Stream mu&longs;t have the
&longs;ame Projecture, but then it will not look ami&longs;s
to have them le&longs;s acute, and as it were blunt­
ed.

From the Heads of the Piers on each
Side, it will be very proper to rai&longs;e Butre&longs;&longs;es for
the Support of the Bridge, in Thickne&longs;s not
le&longs;s than two thirds of the Pier it&longs;elf.

The
Crowns of all the Arches mu&longs;t &longs;tand quite clear
above the Water: Their Dre&longs;s may be taken
from the Ionic or rather the Doric Architrave,
and in large Bridges it mu&longs;t not be le&longs;s in
Breadth than the fifteenth Part of the whole
Aperture of the Arch.

To make the Rail or
Side-wall of the Bridge the &longs;tronger, erect Pe­
de&longs;tals at certain Di&longs;tances by the Square and
Plum-line, on which, if you plea&longs;e, you may
rai&longs;e Columns to &longs;upport a Roof or Portico.

The Height of this Side-wall with its Zocle
and Cornice mu&longs;t be four Foot.

The Spaces
between the Pede&longs;tals may be filled up with a
&longs;light Brea&longs;t-wall.

The Crown both of the
Pede&longs;tals and Brea&longs;t-wall may be an upright
Cymatium, or rather a rever&longs;ed one, continu­
ed the whole Length of the Bridge, and the
Plinth at Bottom mu&longs;t an&longs;wer this Cymatium.

The Cau&longs;eway on each Side for Women and
Foot Pa&longs;&longs;engers mu&longs;t be rai&longs;ed a Foot or two
higher than the Middle of the Bridge, which
being intended chiefly for Bea&longs;ts of Carriage,
may be paved only with Flints.

The Height
of the Columns, with their Intablature, mu&longs;t
be equal to the Breadth of the Bridge.

The
Cro&longs;&longs;ways and Squares differ only in their Big­
ne&longs;s, the Cro&longs;&longs;way being indeed nothing el&longs;e but
a &longs;mall Square. Plato ordained that in all Cro&longs;&longs;­
ways there &longs;hould be Spaces left for Nur&longs;es to
meet in with their Children.

His De&longs;ign in
this Regulation was, I &longs;uppo&longs;e, not only that
the Children might grow &longs;trong by being in the
Air, but al&longs;o that the Nur&longs;es them&longs;elves, by
&longs;eeing one another, might grow neater and
more delicate, and be le&longs;s liable to Negligence
among &longs;o many careful Ob&longs;ervers in the &longs;ame
Bu&longs;ine&longs;s.

It is certain, one of the greate&longs;t Or­
naments either of a Square, or of a Cro&longs;&longs;way,
is a hand&longs;ome Portico, under which the old
Men may &longs;pend the Heat of the Day, or be
mutually &longs;erviceable to each other; be&longs;ides that
the Pre&longs;ence of the Fathers may deter and re­
&longs;train the Youth, who are &longs;porting and divert­
ing them&longs;elves in the other Part of the Place,
from the Mi&longs;chievou&longs;ne&longs;s and Folly natural to
their Age.

The Squares mu&longs;t be &longs;o many dif­
&longs;erent Markets, one for Gold and Silver, an­
other for Herbs, another for Cattle, another for
Wood, and &longs;o on; each whereof ought to have
its particular Place in the City, and its di&longs;tinct
Ornaments; but that where the Traffick of
Gold and Silver is to be carried on, ought to
be much the Noble&longs;t?

The Greeks made their
Forums or Markets exactly &longs;quare, and encom­
pa&longs;&longs;ed them with large double Porticoes, which
they adorned with Columns and their Intabla­
tures, all of Stone, with noble Terra&longs;&longs;es at the
Top, for taking the Air upon.

Among our
Countrymen the Italians, the Forums u&longs;ed to
be a third Part longer than they were broad:
And becau&longs;e in ancient Times they were the
Places where the Shows of the Gladiators were
exhibited, the Columns in the Porticoes were
&longs;et at a greater Di&longs;tance from each other, that
they might not ob&longs;truct the Sight of tho&longs;e Di­
ver&longs;ions.

In the Porticoes were the Shows for
the Gold&longs;miths, and over the fir&longs;t Story were
Galleries projecting out for &longs;eeing the Shows
in, and the publick Magazines.

This was the
Method among the Ancients.

For my Part I
would have a Square twice as long as broad,
and that the Porticoes and other Buildings about
it &longs;hould an&longs;wer in &longs;ome Proportion to the open
Area in the Middle, that it may not &longs;eem too
large, by means of the Lowne&longs;s of the Build­
ings, nor too &longs;mall, from their being too high.

A proper Height for the Buildings about a
Square is one third of the Breadth of the open
Area, or one &longs;ixth at the lea&longs;t.

I would al&longs;o
have the Porticoes rai&longs;ed above the Level of
the Ground, one fifth Part of their Breadth,
and that their Breadth &longs;hould be equal to half
the Height of their Columns, including the
Intablature.

The Proportions of the Columns
&longs;hould be taken from tho&longs;e of the Ba&longs;ilique,
only with this Difference, that here the Archi­
trave, Freze and Cornice together &longs;hould be
one fifth of the Column in Height.

If you
would make a &longs;econd Row of Columns over
this fir&longs;t, tho&longs;e Columns &longs;hould be one fourth
Part thinner and &longs;horter than tho&longs;e below, and
for a Ba&longs;ement to them you mu&longs;t make a
Plinth half the Height of the Ba&longs;ement at the
Bottom.

But nothing can be a greater Orna­
ment either to Squares or the Meeting of &longs;eve­
ral Streets, than Arches at the Entrance of the
Streets; an Arch being indeed nothing el&longs;e but
a Gate &longs;tanding continually open.

I am of
Opinion, that the Invention of Arches were
owing to tho&longs;e that fir&longs;t enlarged the Bounds
of the Empire: For it was the ancient Cu&longs;tom
with &longs;uch, as we are informed by Tacitus, to
enlarge the Pomoerium, or vacant Space left
next the City Walls, as we find particularly
that Claudius did.

Now though they extend­
ed the Limits of the City, yet they thought it
proper to pre&longs;erve the old Gates, for &longs;everal
Rea&longs;ons, and particularly becau&longs;e they might
&longs;ome Time or other happen to be a Safeguard
again&longs;t the Irruption of an Enemy.

Afterwards

Of the adorning Theatres and other Places for publick Shows, and of their
U&longs;efulne&longs;s.

We come now to Places for publick
Shows.

We are told that Epimenides,
the &longs;ame that &longs;lept fifty-&longs;even Years in a Cave;
when the Athenians were building a Place for
publick Shows reproved them, telling them, you
know not how much Mi&longs;chief this Place &longs;hall
occa&longs;ion; if you did, you would pull it to
Pieces with your Teeth.

Neither dare I pre­
&longs;ume to find Fault with our Pontiffs, and tho&longs;e
who&longs;e Bu&longs;ine&longs;s it is to &longs;et good Examples to
others, for having, with good Cau&longs;e no doubt,
aboli&longs;hed the U&longs;e of publick Shows.

Yet Mo&longs;es
was commended for ordaining, that all his Peo­
ple &longs;hould upon certain &longs;olemn Days meet to­
gether in one Temple, and celebrate publick
Fe&longs;tivals at &longs;tated Sea&longs;ons.

What may we &longs;up­
po&longs;e his View to have been in this In&longs;titution?

Doubtle&longs;s he hoped the People, by thus meet­
ing frequently together at publick Fea&longs;ts, might
grow more humane, and be the clo&longs;er linked
in Friend&longs;hip one with another.

So I imagine
our Ance&longs;tors in&longs;tituted publick Shows in the
City, not &longs;o much for the Sake of the Diver&longs;i­
ons them&longs;elves, as for their U&longs;efulne&longs;s.

And
indeed if we examine the Matter thoroughly,
we &longs;hall find many Rea&longs;ons to grieve that &longs;o
excellent and &longs;o u&longs;eful an Entertainment &longs;hould
have been &longs;o long di&longs;u&longs;ed: For as of the&longs;e
publick Diver&longs;ions &longs;ome were contrived for the
Delight and Amu&longs;ement of Peace and Lei&longs;ure,
others for an Exerci&longs;e of War and Bu&longs;ine&longs;s;
the one &longs;erved wonderfully to revive and keep
up the Vigour and Fire of the Mind, and the
other to improve the Strength and Intrepidity
of the Heart.

It is indeed true that &longs;ome cer­
tain and con&longs;tant Medium &longs;hould be ob&longs;erved,
in order to make the&longs;e Entertainments u&longs;eful
and ornamental to a Country.

The Arcadi­
ans, we are told, were the fir&longs;t that invented
publick Games, to civilize and poli&longs;h the Minds
of their People, who had been too much ac­
cu&longs;tomed to a hard and &longs;evere Way of Life;
and Polybius writes, that tho&longs;e who afterwards
left off tho&longs;e Entertainments, grew &longs;o barbarous
and cruel, that they became execrable to all
Greece.

But indeed the Memory of publick
Games is extremely ancient, and the Invention
of them is a&longs;cribed to various Per&longs;ons. Diony&longs;i­
us is &longs;aid to have been the fir&longs;t Inventor of
Dances and Sports, as Hercules was of the Di­
ver&longs;ion of the Combate.

We read that the
Olympick Games were invented by the Æto­
lians and the Eleans, after their return from the
Siege of Troy.

We are told, that Diony&longs;ius of
Lemnos, who was the Inventor of the Chorus
in Tragedies, was al&longs;o the fir&longs;t that built a
Place on purpo&longs;e for publick Shows.

In Italy,
Lucius Mummius, upon Occa&longs;ion of his Tri­
umph, fir&longs;t introduced theatrical Entertain­
ments two hundred Years before the Em­
peror Nero's Time, and the Actors were
brought to Rome from Etruria.

Hor&longs;e-Races
were brought from the Tyrians, and almo&longs;t the
whole Variety of publick Diver&longs;ions came to
Italy from A&longs;ia. I am inclined to believe that
the ancient Race of Men, that fir&longs;t began to
cut the Figure of Janus upon their brazen
Coins, were content to &longs;tand to &longs;ee the&longs;e Sort
of Games under &longs;ome Beech or Elm, according
to tho&longs;e Ver&longs;es of Ovid, &longs;peaking of Romulus's
Show.

His Play-hou&longs;e, not of Parian Marble made,
Nor was it &longs;pread with purple Sails for &longs;hade.

The Stage with Ru&longs;hes or with Leaves they &longs;trew'd:
No Scenes in Pro&longs;pect, no machining God.
On Rows of homely Turf they &longs;at to &longs;ee,
Crown'd with the Wreaths of every common Tree.

HOWEVER, we read that Jolaus, the Son of
Iphiclus, fir&longs;t contrived Seats for the Spectators
in Sardinia, when he received the The&longs;piad
from Hercules.

But at fir&longs;t Theatres were
built only of Wood; and we find that Pompey
was blamed for having made the Seats fixed
and not moveable, as they u&longs;ed to be anciently:
But Diver&longs;ions of this Nature were afterwards
carried to &longs;uch a Height, that there were no
le&longs;s than three va&longs;t Theatres within the City of
Rome, be&longs;ides &longs;everal Amphitheatres, one of
which was &longs;o large that it would hold above
two hundred thou&longs;and Per&longs;ons, be&longs;ides the Cir­
cus Maximus: All which were built of &longs;quare
Stone and adorned with Columns of Marble.

Nay, not content with all the&longs;e, they erected
Theatres, only for temporary Entertainments,
prodigiou&longs;ly enriched with Marble, Gla&longs;s, and
great Numbers of Statues.

The noble&longs;t Struc­
ture in tho&longs;e Days, and the mo&longs;t capacious,
which was at Placentia, a Town in Lombardy,
was burnt in the Time of Octavianus's War.

But we &longs;hall dwell no longer upon this ancient
Magnificence.

Of publick Shows, &longs;ome are
proper to Peace and Lei&longs;ure, others to War and
Bu&longs;ine&longs;s.

Tho&longs;e proper to Lei&longs;ure, belong to
the Poets, Mu&longs;icians and Actors: Tho&longs;e pro­
per to War, are Wre&longs;tling, Boxing, Fencing,
Shooting, Running, and every Thing el&longs;e re­
lating to the Exerci&longs;e of Arms. Plato ordained
that Shows of this la&longs;t Nature &longs;hould be exhi­
bited every Year, as highly tending to the
Welfare and Ornament of a City.

The&longs;e Di­
ver&longs;ions required various Buildings, which there­
fore have been called by various Names.

Tho&longs;e
de&longs;igned for the U&longs;e of the Poets, Comick,
Tragick and the like, are called Theatres by
way of Excellence.

The Place where the no­
ble Youth exerci&longs;ed them&longs;elves in driving Races
in Chariots with two or four Hor&longs;es, was called
the Circus.

That la&longs;tly, where wild Bea&longs;t
were enclo&longs;ed and baited, was called an Am­
phitheatre.

Almo&longs;t all the Structures for the&longs;e
different Sorts of Shows were built in Imitation
of the Figure of an Army drawn up in Order
of Battle, with its two Horns or Wings pro­
tending forwards, and con&longs;i&longs;ted of an Area
wherein the Actors, or Combatants, or Chari­
ots are to exhibit the Spectacle, and of Rows
of Seats around for the Spectators to &longs;it on:
But then they differ as to the Form of the afore­
&longs;aid Area; for tho&longs;e which have this Area in
the Shape of a Moon in its Decrea&longs;e are called
Theatres, but when the Horns are protracted
a great Way forwards, they are called Circu&longs;&longs;es,
becau&longs;e in them the Chariots make a Circle
about the Goal.

Some tell us, that the Anci­
ents u&longs;ed to celebrate Games of this Kind in
Rings between Rivers and Swords (interen&longs;es &
flumina) and that therefore they were called
Circen&longs;es, and that the Inventor of the&longs;e Di­
ver&longs;ions was one Monagus at Elis in A&longs;ia.

The
Area inclo&longs;ed between the Fronts of two Thea­
tres joined together was called Cavea, or the
Pit, and the whole Edifice an Amphitheatre.

The Situation of a Building for publick Shows
ought particularly to be cho&longs;en in a good Air,
that the Spectators may not be incommoded
either by Wind, Sun, or any of the other In­
conveniences mentioned in the fir&longs;t Book, and
the Theatre ought in an e&longs;pecial Manner to
be &longs;heltered from the Sun, becau&longs;e it is in the
Month of Augu&longs;t chiefly, as Horace ob&longs;erves,
that the People are fond of the Recitals of the
Poets, and the lighter Recreations: And if the
Rays of the Sun beat in, and were confined
within any Part of the Theatre, the exce&longs;&longs;ive
Heat might be apt to throw the Spectators into
Di&longs;tempers.

The Place ought al&longs;o to be pro­
per for Sound, and it is very convenient to have
Porticoes, either adjoining to the Theatre, or
at an ea&longs;y Di&longs;tance from it, for People to &longs;hel­
ter them&longs;elves under from &longs;udden Rains and
Storms. Plato was for having the Theatre
within the City, and the Circus &longs;omewhere out
of it.

The Parts of the ancient Theatres were
as follows: The Area or open Space in the
Middle, which was quite uncovered; about
this Area, the Rows of Seats for the Specta­
tors, and oppo&longs;ite to them the rai&longs;ed Floor or
Stage for the Actors, and the Decorations pro­
per to the Repre&longs;entation, and at the Top of
all, Colonades and Arches to receive the Actor's
Voice, and make it more &longs;onorous.

But the
Greek Theatres differed from tho&longs;e of the Ro­
mans in this Particular, that the Greeks brought
their Choru&longs;es and Actors within the Area,
and by that Means had Occa&longs;ion for a &longs;maller
Stage, whereas the Romans having the whole
Performance upon the Pulpitum, or Stage, be­
yond the Semicircle of the Seats, were obliged
to make their Stage much larger.

In this they
all agreed, that at fir&longs;t in marking out the Plat­
form for the Theatre, they made u&longs;e of a Se­
micircle, only drawing out the Horns &longs;ome­
what farther than to be exactly &longs;emicircular,
with a Line which &longs;ome made &longs;trait, others
curve.

Tho&longs;e who extended them with Strait­
lines, drew them out beyond the Semicircle,
parallel to each other, to the Addition of one
fourth Part of the Diameter: But tho&longs;e who
extended them with Curve-lines, fir&longs;t mark'd
out a compleat Circle, and then taking off one
fourth Part of its Circumference, the Remain­
der was left for the Platform of the Theatre.

The Limits of the Area being marked out and
fixed, the next Work was to rai&longs;e the Seats;
and the fir&longs;t Thing to be done in order to this,
was to re&longs;olve how high the Seats &longs;hould be,
and from their Height to calculate how much
of the Platform they mu&longs;t take up.

Mo&longs;t
Architects made the Height of the Theatre
equal to the Area in the Middle, knowing that
in low Theatres the Voice was &longs;unk and lo&longs;t,
but made &longs;tronger and clearer in high ones.

Some of the be&longs;t Arti&longs;ts made the Height of
the Building to be four fifths of the Breadth
of the Area.

Of this whole Height the Seats
never took up le&longs;s than half, nor more than
two thirds, and their Breadth was &longs;ometimes
equal to their Height, and &longs;ometimes only two
fifths of it.

I &longs;hall here de&longs;cribe one of the&longs;e
Structures which I think the mo&longs;t compleat
and perfect of any.

The outermo&longs;t Founda­
tions of the Seats, or rather of the Wall again&longs;t
which the highe&longs;t Seat mu&longs;t terminate, mu&longs;t
be laid di&longs;tant from the Center of the Semi­
circle one whole Semidiameter of the Area,
with the Addition of a third.

The fir&longs;t or
lowe&longs;t Seat mu&longs;t not be upon the very Level
of the Area, but be rai&longs;ed upon a Wall, which
in the larger Theatres mu&longs;t be in Height the
ninth Part of the Semidiameter of the middle
Area, from the Top of which Wall the Seats
mu&longs;t take their fir&longs;t Flight: And in the &longs;malle&longs;t
Theatres, this Wall mu&longs;t never be le&longs;s than
&longs;even Foot high.

The Benches them&longs;elves
mu&longs;t be a Foot and an half high, and two
and an half broad.

Among the&longs;e Seats, Spaces
mu&longs;t be left at certain Di&longs;tances for Pa&longs;&longs;ages
into the middle Area, and for Stairs to go up
from thence to tho&longs;e Seats, which Stair-ca&longs;es
and Pa&longs;&longs;ages &longs;hould be with vaulted Roofs,
and in Number proportionable to the Bigne&longs;s
of the Theatre.

Of the&longs;e Pa&longs;&longs;ages there &longs;hould
be &longs;even principal ones, all directed exactly to
the Center of the Area, and perfectly clear
and open, at equal Di&longs;tances from each other;
and of the&longs;e &longs;even, one &longs;hould be larger than
the re&longs;t, an&longs;wering to the middle of the Semi­
circle, which I call the Ma&longs;ter Entrance, be­
cau&longs;e it mu&longs;t an&longs;wer to the high Street.

An­
other Pa&longs;&longs;age mu&longs;t be made at the Head of
the Semicircle on the Right Hand, and &longs;o an­
other on the Le&longs;t to an&longs;wer it, and between
the&longs;e and the Ma&longs;ter Entrance four others, two
on each Side.

There may be as many other
Openings and Pa&longs;&longs;ages as the Compa&longs;s of the
Theatre requires, and will admit of.

The
Ancients in their great Theatres divided the
Rows of Seats into three Parts, and each of
the&longs;e Divi&longs;ions was di&longs;tingui&longs;hed from the other
by a Seat twice as broad as the others, which
was a Kind of Landing-place, &longs;eparating the
higher Seats from the lower; and at the&longs;e
Landing-places, the Stairs for coming up to
the &longs;everal Seats terminated.

I have ob&longs;erved,
that the be&longs;t Architects, and the mo&longs;t inge­
nious Contrivers u&longs;ed at each great Entrance
to make two different Stairs, one more upright
and direct, for the Young and the Nimble,
and another broader and ea&longs;ier, with more fre­
quent Re&longs;ts, for the Matrons and old People.
This may &longs;uffice as to the Seats.

Oppo&longs;ite to
the Front of the Theatre was rai&longs;ed the Stage
for the Actors, and every thing belonging to
the Repre&longs;entation, and here &longs;ate the Nobles
in peculiar and honourable Seats, &longs;eparate from
the common People, or perhaps in the middle
Area in hand&longs;ome Places erected for that Pur­
po&longs;e.

The Pulpitum or Stage, was made &longs;o
large as to be fully &longs;ufficient for every thing
that was to be acted upon it.

It came forward
equal to the Center of the Semicircle, and was
rai&longs;ed in Height not above five Foot, that the
Nobles who &longs;ate in the Area might from thence
ea&longs;ily &longs;ee every Ge&longs;ture of the Actors.

But
when the middle Area was not re&longs;erved for the
Nobles to &longs;it in, but was allowed to the Actors
and Mu&longs;icians: Then the Stage was made le&longs;s,
but rai&longs;ed higher, &longs;ometimes to the Height of
&longs;ix Cubits.

In both Kinds the Stage was adorn­
ed with Rows of Colonades one over another,
in Imitation of Hou&longs;es, with their proper Doors
and Windows, and in Front was one principal
Door with all the Dre&longs;s of the Door of a
Temple, to repre&longs;ent a Royal Palace, with
other Doors on each Side for the Actors to
make their Entrances and Exits at, according
to the Nature of the Drama.

And as there
are three Sorts of Poets concerned in theatrical
Performances, the Tragick, who de&longs;cribe the
Misfortunes and Di&longs;tre&longs;&longs;es of Princes; the Co­
mick who repre&longs;ent the Lives and Manners of
private Per&longs;ons, and the Pa&longs;toral, who &longs;ing the
Delights of the Country, and the Loves of
Shepherds: There was a Contrivance upon the
Stage of a Machine which turning upon a Pin,
in an In&longs;tant changed the Scene to a Palace
for Tragedy, an ordinary Hou&longs;e for Comedy,
or a Grove for Pa&longs;toral, as the Nature of the
Fable required.

Such was the Manner of the
Middle, Area, Seats and Stage, Pa&longs;&longs;ages and
the like.

I have already &longs;aid in this Chapter,
that one of the principal Parts of the Theatre
was the Portico, which was de&longs;igned for ren­
dering the Sound of the Voice &longs;tronger and
clearer.

This was placed upon the highe&longs;t
Seat, and the Front of its Colonade looked to
the middle Area of the Theatre.

Of this we
are now to give &longs;ome Account.

THE Ancients had learnt from the Philo&longs;o­
phers, that the Air, by the Percu&longs;&longs;ion of the
Voice, and the Force of Sound, was put into a
circular Motion, in the &longs;ame Manner as Water
is when any thing is &longs;uddenly plunged into it,
and that, as for In&longs;tance, in a Lute, or in a
Valley, between two Hills, e&longs;pecially if the
Place be woody, the Sound and Voice are ren­
dered much more clear and &longs;trong, becau&longs;e the
&longs;welling Circles of the Air meet with &longs;ome­
thing which beats back the Rays of the Voice
that i&longs;&longs;ue from the Center, in the &longs;ame Man­
ner as a Ball is beat back from a Wall again&longs;t
which it is thrown, by which means tho&longs;e Cir­
cles are made clo&longs;er and &longs;tronger: For this
Rea&longs;on the Ancients built their Theatres cir­
cular; and that the Voice might meet with no
Ob&longs;tacle to &longs;top its free A&longs;cent to the very
highe&longs;t Part of the Theatre, they placed their
Seats in &longs;uch a Manner, that all the Angles of
them lay in one exact Line, and upon the
highe&longs;t Seat, which was no &longs;mall Help, they
rai&longs;ed Porticoes facing the middle Area of the
Theatre, the Front of which Porticoes were as
open and free as po&longs;&longs;ible, but the Back of them
was entirely &longs;hut up with a continued Wall.

Under this Portico they rai&longs;ed a low Wall,
which not only &longs;erved for a Pede&longs;tal to the
Columns, but al&longs;o helped to collect the &longs;welling
Orbs of the Voice, and to throw it gently into
the Portico it&longs;elf, where being received into a
thicker Air, it was not reverberated from thence
too violently, but returned clear and a little
more &longs;trengthened.

And over all this, as a
Cieling to the Theatre, both to keep off the
Weather, and to retain the Voice, they &longs;pread
a Sail all &longs;trewed over with Stars, which they
could remove at Plea&longs;ure, and which &longs;haded
the middle Area, the Seats, and all the Specta­
tors.

The upper Portico was built with a
great deal of Art; for in order to &longs;upport it,
there were other Porticoes and Colonades at
the Back of the Theatre, out to the Street, and
in the larger Theatres, the&longs;e Porticoes were
made double, that if any violent Rain or Storm
obliged the Spectators to fly for Shelter, it
might not drive in upon them.

The&longs;e Porti­
coes and Colonades, thus placed under the up­
per Portico, were not like tho&longs;e which we have
de&longs;cribed for Temples or Ba&longs;iliques, but built
of &longs;trong Pila&longs;ters, and in Imitation of tri­
umphal Arches.

We &longs;hall fir&longs;t therefore treat
of the&longs;e under Porticoes, as being built for the
Sake of that above.

The Rule for the Aper­
tures of the&longs;e Porticoes is, that to every Pa&longs;&longs;age
into the middle Area of the Theatre, there
ought to be one of them, and each of the&longs;e
Apertures &longs;hould be accompanied with others
in certain Proportions, an&longs;wering exactly one to
the other in Height, Breadth, De&longs;ign and Or­
naments.

The Breadth of the Area for walk­
ing in the&longs;e Porticoes, &longs;hould be equal to the
Aperture between Pila&longs;ter and Pila&longs;ter, and the
Breadth of each Pila&longs;ter &longs;hould be equal to half
that Aperture: All which Rules mu&longs;t be ob­
&longs;erved with the greate&longs;t Care and Exactne&longs;s.

La&longs;tly, again&longs;t the&longs;e Pila&longs;ters we mu&longs;t not &longs;et
Columns entirely in&longs;ulate, as in triumphal
Arches, but only three quarter Columns with
Pede&longs;tals under them, in Height one &longs;ixth of
the Column it&longs;elf.

The other Ornaments mu&longs;t
be the &longs;ame as tho&longs;e in Temples.

The Height
of the&longs;e three quarter Columns, with their
whole Entablature, mu&longs;t be equal to half the
perpendicular Height of the Seats within, &longs;o
that on the Out&longs;ide there mu&longs;t be two Orders
of Columns one over the other, the &longs;econd of
which mu&longs;t be ju&longs;t even with the Top of tho&longs;e
Seats, and over this we mu&longs;t lay the Pavement
for the upper Portico, which as we &longs;hewed be­
fore, mu&longs;t look into the middle Area of the
Theatre, in Shape re&longs;embling a Hor&longs;e-&longs;hoe.

This Sub&longs;tructure being laid, we are to rai&longs;e
our upper Portico, the Front and Colonade
whereof is not to receive its Light from with­
out, like tho&longs;e before de&longs;cribed, but is to be
open to the Middle of the Theatre, as we have
already ob&longs;erved.

This Work being rai&longs;ed in
order to prevent the Voice from being lo&longs;t and
di&longs;per&longs;ed, may be called the Circumvallation.

Its Height &longs;hould be the whole Height of the
outer Portico, with the Addition of one half,
and its Parts are the&longs;e.

The low Wall under
the Columns, which we may call a continued
Pede&longs;tal.

This Wall of the whole Height of
the Circumvallation, from the upper Seat to
the Top of the Entablature, mu&longs;t in great
Theatres be allowed never more than a Third,
and in &longs;mall ones, not le&longs;s than a Fourth.

Up­
on this continued Pede&longs;tal &longs;tand the Columns
which with their Ba&longs;es and Capitals mu&longs;t be
equal to half the Height of the whole Circum­
vallation.

Over the&longs;e Columns lies their En­
tablature, and over all a Plain Wall, &longs;uch as we
de&longs;cribed in Ba&longs;iliques, which Wall mu&longs;t be
allowed the &longs;ixth remaining Part of the Height
of the Circumvallation.

The Columns in this
Circumvallation &longs;hall be in&longs;ulate, rai&longs;ed a&longs;ter
the &longs;ame Proportions as tho&longs;e in the Ba&longs;iliques,
and in Number ju&longs;t an&longs;wering to tho&longs;e of the
three quarter Columns &longs;et again&longs;t the Pila&longs;ters
of the outward Portico, and they &longs;hall be
placed exactly in the &longs;ame Rays, by which
Name I under&longs;tand Lines drawn from the Cen­
ter of the Theatre to the outward Columns.

In the low Wall, or continued Pede&longs;tal, &longs;et
under the Columns of the inner Portico, mu&longs;t
be certain Openings, ju&longs;t over the Pa&longs;&longs;ages be­
low into the Theatre, which Openings mu&longs;t
be in the Nature of Niches, wherein, if you
think fit, you may place a Sort of Va&longs;es of
Bra&longs;s, hung with their Mouths downwards,
that the Voice reverberating in them, may be
returned more &longs;onorous.

I &longs;hall not here wa&longs;te
Time in con&longs;idering tho&longs;e In&longs;tructions in Vi­
truvius, which he borrows from the Precepts
of Compo&longs;ition in Mu&longs;ick, according to the
Rules of which he is for placing the ju&longs;t men­
tioned Va&longs;es in Theatres, &longs;o as to corre&longs;pond
with the differerent Pitches of the &longs;everal
Voices: A Curio&longs;ity ea&longs;ily talked of, but how
it is to be executed, let tho&longs;e inform us, who
know.

Thus much I mu&longs;t readily a&longs;&longs;ent to,
and Ari&longs;totle him&longs;elf is of the Opinion, that
hollow Ve&longs;&longs;els of any Sort, and Wells too, are
of Service in &longs;trengthening the Sound of the
Voice.

But to return to the Portico on the
In&longs;ide of the Theatre.

The back Wall of this
Portico mu&longs;t be quite clo&longs;e and entire, and &longs;o
&longs;hut in the whole Circumvallation, that the
Voice arriving there, may not be lo&longs;t.

On the
Out&longs;ide of the Wall to the Street, we may ap­
ply Columns as Ornaments, in Number,
Height, Proportions and Members, exactly an­
&longs;wering to tho&longs;e in the Porticoes under them,
in the outward Front of the Theatre.

From
what has been &longs;aid, it is ea&longs;y to collect in what
Particulars the greater Theatres differ from the
&longs;maller.

In the greater, the outward Portico
below is double, in the &longs;maller &longs;ingle: In the
former, there may be three Orders of Columns,
one over the other; in the latter, not more
than two.

They al&longs;o differ in this, that &longs;ome
&longs;mall Theatres have no Portico at all on the
In&longs;ide, but for their Circumvallation, have on­
ly a plain Wall and a Cornice, which is in­
tended for the &longs;ame Purpo&longs;e of returning the
Voice, as the Portico in great Theatres, and
in &longs;ome of the large&longs;t Theatres, even this in­
ward Portico is double.

La&longs;tly, the outward
Covering of the Theatre mu&longs;t be well plai&longs;ter­
ed or coated, and made &longs;o &longs;loping that the
Water may run into Pipes placed in the Angles
of the Building, which mu&longs;t carry it off private­
ly into proper Drains.

Upon the upper Cor­
nice on the Out&longs;ide of the Theatre, Mutules
and Stays mu&longs;t be contrived to &longs;upport Poles,
like the Ma&longs;ts of Ships to which to fa&longs;ten the
Ropes for &longs;preading the Vela or Covering of
the Theatre upon any extraordinary Repre&longs;en­
tation.

And as we are to rai&longs;e &longs;o great a Pile
of Building to a ju&longs;t Height, the Wall ought to
be allowed a due Thickne&longs;s for the &longs;upporting
&longs;uch a Weight.

Let the Thickne&longs;s therefore
of the outward Wall of the fir&longs;t Colonade be a
fifteenth Part of the Height of the whole Struc­
ture.

The middle Wall between the two Por­
ticoes, when the&longs;e are double, mu&longs;t want one
fourth Part of the Thickne&longs;s of the outward
one.

The next Story rai&longs;ed above this may be
a twelfth Part thinner than the lower one.
CHAP. VIII.

Of the Ornaments of the Amphitheatre, Circus, publick Walks, and Halls,
and Courts for petty Judges.

Having &longs;aid thus much of Theatres,
it is nece&longs;&longs;ary to give &longs;ome Account
of the Circus and Amphitheatre which all owe
their Original to the Theatre, for the Circus is
indeed nothing el&longs;e but a Theatre with its
Horns &longs;tretched further on in Lines equi-di&longs;­
tant one from the other, only that the Nature
of this Building does not require Portices; and
the Amphitheatre is formed of two Theatres
with their Horns joined together, and the
Rows of Seats continued quite round; and
the chief Difference between them is, that a
Theatre is properly an half Amphitheatre,
with this further Variation too, that the Am­
phitheatre has its middle Area quite clear from
any Thing of a Stage or Scenes; but in all
other re&longs;pects, and particularly in the Seats,
Porticoes, Entrances and the like, they exactly
agree.

I am inclined to believe, that the Am­
phitheatre was at fir&longs;t contrived chiefly for
Hunting, and that for this Rea&longs;on it was made
round, to the Intent that the wild Bea&longs;ts
which were enclo&longs;ed and baited in it, not
having any Nook or Corner to fly to, might
be the &longs;ooner obliged to defend them&longs;elves
again&longs;t their A&longs;&longs;ailants, who were extremely
bold and dextrous at engaging with the fier­
ce&longs;t wild Bea&longs;ts.

Some armed only with a
Javelin, would with the Help of that leap
over a wild Bull that was making at him full
Speed, and &longs;o elude his Blow.

Others having
put on a Kind of Armour, compo&longs;ed of no­
thing but thick Thorns and Prickles, would
&longs;uffer them&longs;elves to be rowled about and
mumbled by a Bear.

Others enclo&longs;ed in a
Kind of wooden Cage, teazed and provoked a
Lion, and fome with nothing but a Cloak
about their left Arm, and a &longs;mall Ax or Mal­
let in their right Hand would attack him
openly.

In a Word, if any Man had either
Dexterity to deceive, or Courage and Strength
to cope with wild Bea&longs;ts, he offered him&longs;elf as
a Champion, either merely for the Sake of Ho­
nour, or for Reward.

We read too, that both
in the Theatres and Amphitheatres, the great
Men u&longs;ed to throw Apples, or let fly little Birds
among the Mob, for the Plea&longs;ure of &longs;eeing
them &longs;cramble for them.

The middle Area
of the Amphitheatre, though it is &longs;urrounded
by two Theatres joined together, yet mu&longs;t not
be made &longs;olong as two compleat Theatres would
make it, if their Horns both pretended to meet
each other: But its Length mu&longs;t bear a cer­
tain Proportion to its Breadth.

Some among
the Ancients made the Length eight, and the
Breadth &longs;even Parts, and &longs;ome made the
Breadth three fourths of the Length.

In other
Particulars it agrees with the Theatre: It mu&longs;t
have Porticoes on the Out&longs;ide, and one at the
Top within, over the highe&longs;t Seat, which we
have called the Circumvallation.

We are next
to treat of the Circus.

Some tell us, that this
was built in Imitation of the heavenly Bodies;
for as the Heavens have twelve Hou&longs;es, &longs;o the
Circus has twelve Gates for Entrance; and as
there are &longs;even Planets, &longs;o this has &longs;even Goals,
lying from Ea&longs;t to We&longs;t at a good Di&longs;tance one
from the other, that through them the con­
tending Chariots may hold their Cour&longs;e, as the
Sun and Moon do through the Zodiac; which
they did four-and-twenty Times, in Imitati­
on of the four-and-twenty Hours.

The Con­
currents were al&longs;o divided into four Squadrons,
each of which was di&longs;tingui&longs;hed by its particu­
lar Colour; the one was cloathed in Green, in
Repre&longs;entation of the verdant Spring; another
to denote the flaming Summer in Red; the
third in White, in Imitation of the pale Au­
tumn; and the fourth in dusky Brown for the
gloomy Winter.

The middle Area of the Cir­
cus was neither clear nor open like the Am­
phitheatre, nor taken up with a Stage like the
Theatre, but it was divided Lengthways into
two Cour&longs;es by the Goals or Terms which
were &longs;et up at proper Di&longs;tances, about which
the Hor&longs;es or Men performed their Races.

Of
the&longs;e Goals there were three principal ones,
whereof the Middlemo&longs;t was the chief of all,
and this was a Pile of Stone tapering up to the
Top, upon account of which regular Diminu­
tion, it was called an Obelisk.

The other two
principal Goals were either colo&longs;&longs;al Statues, or
lofty Piles of Stones in the Nature of Trophies,
de&longs;igned a&longs;ter the Workman's Fancy, &longs;o as
they were only great and beauti&longs;ul.

Between
the&longs;e principal Goals were two others on each
Side, either Columns or Obelisks le&longs;s than the
former, which made up the Number of Seven.

We read in Hi&longs;torians, that the Circus Maxi­
mus at Rome was three Furlongs in Length,
and one in Breadth.

Now indeed it is entire­
ly de&longs;troyed, and there are not the lea&longs;t Foot­
&longs;teps remaining by which we can form a Judg­
ment of its ancient Structure: But by an actual
Survey of other Works of this Nature I find the
Manner of them was as follows: The Anci­
ents u&longs;ed to make the middle Area of the Cir­
cus in Breadth at lea&longs;t three&longs;core Cubits, or
ninety Foot, and in Length &longs;even Times that
Breadth.

The Breadth was divided into two
equal Parts or Cour&longs;es by a Line drawn the
Length of the Circus, on which Line the Goals
or Terms were placed according to the follow­
ing Method: The whole Length being divided
into &longs;even Parts, one of tho&longs;e Parts was given
to a Sweep at each End for the Concurrents to
turn out of the right Cour&longs;e into the left, and
the Remainder was allowed for the Goals, which

&longs;tanding at equal Di&longs;tances from each other,
took up the other &longs;ive &longs;evenths of the whole
Length of the Circus.

One Goal was joined to
the other by a Kind of Brea&longs;t-wall which was
never le&longs;s than &longs;ix Foot high, to keep the
Hor&longs;es that were running from cro&longs;&longs;ing out of
one Cour&longs;e into the other.

On each Side of
the Circus were Seats rai&longs;ed to the Height of
never more than the fifth, nor le&longs;s than the
&longs;ixth of the whole Breadth of the middle Area;
and the&longs;e Seats began from a Ba&longs;ement, as in
Amphitheatres, that the Spectators might not
be within reach of any Hurt from the Bea&longs;ts.

Among publick Works we may reckon tho&longs;e
publick Walks, in which the Youth exerci&longs;e
them&longs;elves at Tennis, Leaping, or the U&longs;e of
Arms, and where the old Men walk to take
the Air, or if they are infirm, are carried about
for the Recovery of their Health. Cel&longs;us, the
Phy&longs;ician, &longs;ays, that Exerci&longs;e is much better
in the open Air, than under Cover; but that
they might exerci&longs;e them&longs;elves more commo­
diou&longs;ly even in the Shade, they added Porti­
coes which enclo&longs;ed the whole Square.

The
Square it&longs;elf was &longs;ometimes paved with Marble
and Mo&longs;aick Work, and &longs;ometimes turfed with
Gra&longs;s, and planted with Myrtles, Juniper,
Cypre&longs;s and Cedar Trees.

The Porticoes on
three Sides were &longs;ingle, and &longs;o large, that their
Proportion was two ninth Parts greater than
that of the Forum before treated of in this
Book; but on the fourth Side, which fronted
the South, the Portico was yet more &longs;pacious,
and double.

In Froat it had Doric Columns,
who&longs;e Height was equal to the Breadth of the
Portico; the Columns behind, which divided
the inner Portico from the outward, were
higher than the former one fifth Part, for &longs;up­
porting the Cover, and giving a Slope to the
Roof; and for this Rea&longs;on they made them of
the Ionic Order, Ionic Columns being in their
very Nature taller than the Doric: Though I
cannot &longs;ee why the Cieling of the&longs;e Porticoes
&longs;hould not have been exactly level, which cer­
tainly mu&longs;t have been more beauti&longs;ul to the
Eye.

In both the&longs;e Colonades, the Diameters
of the Columns were as follows: In the Do­
ric, the lower Diameter of the Shaft was two
fifteenths of the whole Height, including the
Ba&longs;e and Capital; but in the Ionic and Corin­
thian, the lower Diameter of the Shaft was
three &longs;ixteenths of the Length of only the Shaft
of the Column.

In other Re&longs;pects they were
the &longs;ame as tho&longs;e u&longs;ed in Temples.

To the
back Walls of the&longs;e Porticoes, they added hand­
&longs;ome Walls or Rooms, where Philo&longs;ophers and
Men of Knowledge might conver&longs;e and di&longs;­
pute upon the noble&longs;t Subjects; and of the&longs;e
Rooms, &longs;ome were proper for Winter, and
others for Summer.

Tho&longs;e which lay any
thing to the North, were for Summer, as
tho&longs;e to the South, and which were not ex­
po&longs;ed to any &longs;harp Winds, were for Winter;
be&longs;ides that tho&longs;e for Winter were &longs;hut in with
entire Walls, whereas tho&longs;e for Summer were
full of Windows, or rather were &longs;eparated only
by a Colonade, and had an open View to­
wards the North, with Pro&longs;pects of Sea, Hills,
Lakes, or &longs;ome other agreeable Landskip, and
admitted as much Light as po&longs;&longs;ible.

The Por­
ticoes on the Right and Left of the&longs;e Squares,
had the &longs;ame Sort of back Rooms, &longs;hut in
from Winds, but open to the Morning and to
the Evening Sun, which &longs;hone in upon them
from the middle Area.

The Plan of the&longs;e
retiring Rooms was various, &longs;ometimes they
were &longs;emicircular, &longs;ometimes rectangular, but
always in a due Proportion to the Square it&longs;elf,
and to the Porticoes which encompa&longs;&longs;ed it
it.

The Breadth of the whole Square with its
Porticoes, was half its Length, and this Breadth
was divided into eight Parts, &longs;ix whereof were
given to the open Square, and one to each
Portico.

When the back retiring Rooms were
&longs;emicircular, their Diameter was two fifths of
the open Area.

In the back Wall of the Por­
ticoes, were the Apertures for Entrance, and
for Light into tho&longs;e Rooms.

The Height of
the &longs;emicircular Retirements, in the greate&longs;t
Proportion, was only equal to their Breadth;
but in &longs;maller Works, it was one fifth Part
more.

Over the Top of the Roof of the Por­
tico, Openings were broke for the Admi&longs;&longs;ion
of a &longs;tronger and more chearful Light into the
Room.

If the&longs;e Withdrawing-rooms were &longs;quare,
then their Breadth was twice the Breadth of the
Porticoes, and their Length twice their own
Breadth.

That I call Length which runs along
with the Portico, &longs;o that upon entering into tho&longs;e
Rooms from the Right, their Length lies to the
Left, and entering them from the Left, to the
Right.

Among publick Works, we are al&longs;o to in­
clude the Portico for the inferior Judges, which
the Ancients u&longs;ed to build after the following
Manner: Their Bigne&longs;s was according to the
Dignity of the City, but rather too large than
too &longs;mall, and along them was a Row of
Chamters, contiguous to each other, where
petty Conte&longs;ts were heard and determined.

Tho&longs;e Works which I have hitherto de&longs;cribed
&longs;eem to be truly publick, as they are de&longs;igned
for the U&longs;e of all the People in general, both
noble and vulgar: But there are &longs;till &longs;ome other
Works of a publick Nature, which are for the
U&longs;e only of the principal Citizens, and of the
Magi&longs;trates; as for In&longs;tance, the Senate-hou&longs;e
and Council-chambers, whereof we are now
to give &longs;ome Account.
CHAP. IX.

Of the proper Ornaments for the Senatc-hou&longs;e and Council-chambers, as al&longs;o of
the adorning the City with Groves, Lakes for Swimming, Libraries, Schools,
publick Stables, Ar&longs;enals and Mathematical In&longs;truments.

Plato appointed the Council to be held
in a Temple, and the Romans had a de­
termined Place for that Purpo&longs;e, which they
called their Comitium.

At Ceraunia there
was a thick Grove, con&longs;ecrated to Jupi­
ter, in which the Greeks u&longs;ed to meet to con­
&longs;ult about the Affairs of their State, and many
other Cities u&longs;ed to hold their Councils in the
Middle of the publick Forum.

It was not
lawful for the Roman Senate to meet in any
Place that was not appointed by Augury, and
they commonly cho&longs;e &longs;ome Temple.

After­
wards they erected Curiæ, or Courts for that
particular Purpo&longs;e, and Varro tells us, that
the&longs;e were of two Sorts: One in which the
Prie&longs;ts con&longs;ulted about religious Matters; the
other where the Senate regulated &longs;ecular Affairs.

Of the peculiar Properties of each of the&longs;e I can
find nothing certain; unle&longs;s we may be allow­
ed to conjecture, that the former had &longs;ome Re­
&longs;emblance to a Temple, the latter to a Ba&longs;ili­
que.

The Prie&longs;ts Court therefore may have a
vaulted Roof, and that of the Senators a flat
one.

In both, the Members of the Council are
to declare their Opinion, by &longs;peaking; and
therefore Regard is to be had in the&longs;e Edifices
to the Sound of the Voice.

For this Rea&longs;on
there ought to be &longs;omething to prevent the
Voice from a&longs;cending too high and being lo&longs;t,
and e&longs;pecially in vaulted Roofs to prevent it
from thundering in the Top of the Vault and
deafening the Hearers: Upon which Account,
as well for Beauty as for this nece&longs;&longs;ary U&longs;e, the
Wall ought to be crowned with a Cornice.

I
find from Ob&longs;ervation of the Structures of this
Sort left by the Ancients, that they u&longs;ed to
make their Courts &longs;quare.

The Height of their
vaulted Courts was &longs;ix &longs;evenths of the Breadth
of the Front, and the Roof was a plain Arch.

Ju&longs;t oppo&longs;ite to the Door the Beholder's Eye
was &longs;truck with the Tribunal, the Sagitta
whereof was the Third of its Chord: The
Breadth of the Aperture of the Door, was one
&longs;eventh of the whole Front.

At half the
Height of the Wall, and one eighth Part of
that half, projected an Architrave, Freze and
Cornice upon an Order of Columns, either clo&longs;e
or thin &longs;et, as the Architect liked be&longs;t, accord­
ing to the Rules of the Colonades and Porti­
coes of a Temple.

Over the Cornice on the
right and left Sides, in certain Niches opened
