with Gla&longs;s, nor &longs;hould every Part be incru&longs;ted
with Hymettian or Parian Marble; &longs;uch Ma­
terials being proper only in Temples: But the
Builder's chief Commendation in a private
Structure, is to u&longs;e moderate Materials elegant­
ly, and elegant ones moderately.

Let him
be contented with Cypre&longs;s, Larch and Box
Wood; let his Incru&longs;tations or outward Coat
be adorned with plain Figures in Stuc, or with
&longs;ome &longs;light Painting, and his Cornices at mo&longs;t
of common Marble.

Not that he mu&longs;t ab&longs;o­
lutely reject the mo&longs;t precious Materials; but
he &longs;hould place them only in the mo&longs;t honour­
able Parts, like Gems in a Crown.

But to give
my Opinion of the whole Matter in one Word,
I think that a &longs;acred Edifice &longs;hould be adorned
in &longs;uch a Manner, that it &longs;hould be impo&longs;&longs;ible
to add any Thing that can conduce either to
Maje&longs;ty, Beauty or Wonder: Whereas a pri­
vate Structure &longs;hould be &longs;o contrived, that it
&longs;hall be impo&longs;&longs;ible to take any Thing from it,
without le&longs;&longs;ening its Dignity.

Other Buildings,
that is to &longs;ay, the Profane of a publick Nature,
&longs;hould ob&longs;erve the Medium between the&longs;e two
Extremes.

Buildings of a private Sort &longs;hould
keep &longs;trictly to the Ornaments proper to them,
only they may be made u&longs;e of here with &longs;ome­
what more Freedom.

For In&longs;tance, if the Co­
lumns be of rather a &longs;maller Diameter, or el&longs;e
more turgid, or if the Diminution of the Top
of the Shaft be greater than the exact Propor­
tions for publick Structures, they ought not
here to be condemned, provided they do not
look deformed or un&longs;ightly.

And whereas in
publick Works not the lea&longs;t Deviation is allow­
ed from the exacte&longs;t Laws of Proportion, in
private Works &longs;uch a Deviation is often hand­
&longs;ome and commendable.

Thus we may ob­
&longs;erve with what a beautiful Effect &longs;ome of the
more lively Architects u&longs;ed in the Doors of
Halls, in&longs;tead of Jambs to place huge Statues
of Slaves, which &longs;upported the Lintel on their
Heads; and to make Columns, e&longs;pecially in the
Porticoes of their Gardens, with Knots in the
Shafts, in Imitation of Trees that had their
Branches cut off, or girded round with a Cinc­
ture of Boughs, or with their whole Shaft
wreathed and enriched with Leaves, Birds, and
Channels: or where they would make the
Work extremely &longs;trong, we find them erect­
ing &longs;quare Columns, fortified with a half Co­
lumn on each Side; which in&longs;tead of Capitals
had either Baskets full of Vine Branches laden
with Fruit, or the Head of a Palm-tree ri&longs;ing
up and full of Leaves, or a Knot of Serpents
wreathed together, or an Eagle with its Wings
expanded in Token of Plea&longs;ure, or a Medu&longs;a's
Head with the Snakes hi&longs;&longs;ing at each other, or
any other Fancy of the &longs;ame Kind; to enu­
merate all which, would be endle&longs;s.

But in all
the&longs;e Liberties the Architect mu&longs;t be as care­
ful as po&longs;&longs;ible to keep the &longs;everal Parts within
the Terms of the regular Lines and Angles, and
not &longs;uffer his Work to want a due Proportion
in its &longs;everal Members: So that the Beholder
may immediately find, that his De&longs;ign was to
be wanton in the&longs;e Particulars, and to indulge a
Freedom of Invention.

And as of the Parlours,
Pa&longs;&longs;ages and Apartments, &longs;ome are more pub­
lick, &longs;ome more concealed, and as it were hid­
den; the former may be allowed &longs;omewhat
more of the Splendor of a publick Structure,
but yet &longs;o as not to create Envy; and in the
latter we may allow our&longs;elves more Liberty in
departing out of the common Road, and con­
triving &longs;omething new.
CHAP. II.
Of the Adorning of private Hou&longs;es, both in City and Country.

But as of the Hou&longs;es of private Per&longs;ons,
&longs;ome are in the City, and &longs;ome in the
Country, we mu&longs;t &longs;ay &longs;omething of the Orna­
ments proper to each of the&longs;e.

Between a
Hou&longs;e in Town and a Hou&longs;e in the Country,
there is this further Difference, be&longs;ides what we
took notice of in the la&longs;t Book, that the Orna­
ments, for that in Town ought to be much
more grave than tho&longs;e for a Hou&longs;e in the Coun­
try, where all the gaye&longs;t and mo&longs;t licentious
Embelli&longs;hments are allowable.

There is an­
other Difference too between them, which is,
that in Town you are obliged to moderate
your&longs;elves in &longs;everal Re&longs;pects according to the
Privileges of your Neighbour; whereas you have
much more Liberty in the Country.

In Town
you mu&longs;t not rai&longs;e your Platform or Ba&longs;ement
too high above your Neighbours, nor let your
Portico project too far forwards from the Line
of the adjacent Buildings.

The Thickne&longs;s and
Height of the Walls at Rome anciently were
not &longs;uffered to be according to every Man's
particular Fancy, but by an old Law were all
to be made according to a certain Standard;
and Julius Cæ&longs;ar, upon account of the Mi&longs;­
chiefs that might happen from bad Foundati­
ons, ordained that no Hou&longs;e &longs;hould be more
than one Story high: To which Regulations a
Country-hou&longs;e is not &longs;ubject.

It was reckoned
one of the Glories of Babylon, that their Hou&longs;es
had Inhabitants in the fourth Story. Ælius
Ari&longs;tides, the Orator, prai&longs;ing Rome in a pub­
lick Oration, cried it up as a miraculous Work
of the Romans to have built upon great Hou&longs;es
other Hou&longs;es as great: a hand&longs;ome Piece of
Flattery; but it &longs;hewed the Numerou&longs;ne&longs;s of
the People much more than the Magnificence
of the Buildings them&longs;elves.

We are told that
in Height of Hou&longs;es the City of Rome was out­
done by Tyre, which by that means was former­
ly very near being wholly de&longs;troyed by Earth­
quakes.

It is one very great Beauty and Con­
venience in a Building to have no more A&longs;cents
and De&longs;cents in it than are ab&longs;olutely nece&longs;&longs;ary;
and it is certainly a very true Saying, that
Stairs are nothing but Incumbrances to a Hou&longs;e,
from which Incumbrances I find the Ancients
were very &longs;tudious to keep clear.

But in the
Country there is no Manner of Nece&longs;&longs;ity for
&longs;etting one Hou&longs;e thus upon another: For on­
ly taking a larger Platform we may make
whatever Conveniencies we think fit upon the
&longs;ame Floor; which I &longs;hould like extremely
well in Town too, if it could be had.

There
is another Sort of private Hou&longs;es, in which the
Dignity of the Town-hou&longs;e, and the Delights
and Plea&longs;ures of the Country-hou&longs;e are both
required; of which we &longs;aid nothing in the for­
mer Books, re&longs;erving it purpo&longs;ely for this very
Place: And the&longs;e are the Plea&longs;ure-hou&longs;es ju&longs;t
without the Town, or the Villa's which are by
no means to be pa&longs;&longs;ed by without &longs;ome Ob&longs;er­
vations, though I &longs;hall be as brief in them as
po&longs;&longs;ible.

Accordingly I &longs;hall here lay together
all that I have to &longs;ay of each of the&longs;e three
Sorts of Structures, and fir&longs;t of the Villa clo&longs;e
to the Town.

The Saying among the Anci­
ents, Let him that buys a Country-hou&longs;e &longs;ell
his Hou&longs;e in Town, and let him that has Bu&longs;i­
ne&longs;s in Town, never think of a Hou&longs;e in the
Country, &longs;eems to imply, that a Villa near
Town is extremely convenient.

The Phy&longs;ici­
ans advi&longs;e us to dwell in the cleare&longs;t and open­
e&longs;t Air that we can find; and there is no room
to doubt but a Country-hou&longs;e &longs;eated upon an
Eminence, mu&longs;t of Cour&longs;e be the Be&longs;t: But
then on the other Hand, the Ma&longs;ter of a Fa­
mily, upon account of his private Bu&longs;ine&longs;s, or
the publick Affairs, may be obliged to be often
in the City; for which Purpo&longs;e a Hou&longs;e in
Town &longs;eems nece&longs;&longs;ary: But then as the former
is inconvenient for Bu&longs;ine&longs;s, &longs;o the latter is
prejudicial to the Health.

It is a common
Thing for the Generals of Armies to remove
their Camps often, to avoid being incommod­
ed by ill Smells: What can we think then of a
great City, where &longs;uch va&longs;t Quantities of Filth,
and &longs;o long kept, are continually exhaling their
offen&longs;ive Steams?

To reconcile this Dilemma
therefore, I do not think that of all the Struc­
tures which are rai&longs;ed for the Conveniency of
Mankind, there is any &longs;o commodious or &longs;o
healthy as the Villa; which at the &longs;ame Time
as it lies in the Way for Bu&longs;ine&longs;s, is not wholly
de&longs;titute of pure Air. Cicero de&longs;ired his Friend
Atticus to build him a Villa in a Place of emi­
nent Note: But I, for my Part, am not for ha­
ving it in a Place of &longs;uch Re&longs;ort, that I mu&longs;t
never venture to appear at my Door without
being compleatly dre&longs;&longs;ed.

I would have it
afford me the Plea&longs;ure which the old Gentle­
man in Terence boa&longs;ts he enjoyed, of being never
tired either with the Town or Country.

Martial
too gives a very ju&longs;t De&longs;cription of his Way of
Living in &longs;uch a Villa.

You tell me, Friend, you much de&longs;ire to know,
What in my Villa I can find to do?

I eat, drink, &longs;ing, play, bathe, sleep, eat again,
Or read, or wanton in the Mu&longs;es Train.

THERE is certainly a va&longs;t deal of Satisfaction
in a convenient Retreat near the Town, where
a Man is at Liberty to do ju&longs;t what he plea&longs;es.

The great Beauties of &longs;uch a Retreat, are being
near the City, upon an open airy Road, and
on a plea&longs;ant Spot of Ground.

The greate&longs;t
Commendation of the Hou&longs;e it&longs;elf is its making
a chearful Appearance to tho&longs;e that go a little
Way out of Town to take the Air, as if it
&longs;eemed to invite every Beholder: And for this
Rea&longs;on I would have it &longs;tand pretty high, but
upon &longs;o ea&longs;y an A&longs;cent, that it &longs;hould hardly
be perceptible to tho&longs;e that go to it, till they
find them&longs;elves at the Top, and a large Pro­
&longs;pect opens it&longs;elf to their View.

Nor &longs;hould
there be any Want of plea&longs;ant Landskips,
flowery Meads, open Champains, &longs;hady Groves,
or limpid Brooks, or clear Streams and Lakes
&longs;or &longs;wimming, with all other Delights of the
&longs;ame Sort, which we before ob&longs;erved to be ne­
ce&longs;&longs;ary in a Country Retreat, both for Conve­
nience and Plea&longs;ure.

La&longs;tly, what I have al­
ready &longs;aid conduces extremely to the Plea&longs;ant­
ne&longs;s of all Buildings, I would have the Front
and whole Body of the Hou&longs;e perfectly well
lighted, and that it be open to receive a great
deal of Light and Sun, and a &longs;ufficient Quan­
tity of whol&longs;ome Air.

Let nothing be within
View that can offend the Eye with a melan­
choly Shade.

Let all Things &longs;mile and &longs;eem
to welcome the Arrival of your Gue&longs;ts.

Let
tho&longs;e who are already entered be in Doubt
whether they &longs;hall for Plea&longs;ure continue where
they are, or pa&longs;s on further to tho&longs;e other Beau­
ties which tempt them on.

Let them be led
from &longs;quare Rooms into round ones, and again
from round into &longs;quare, and &longs;o into others
of mixed Lines, neither all round nor all
&longs;quare; and let the Pa&longs;&longs;age into the very in­
nermo&longs;t Apartments be, if po&longs;&longs;ible, without the
lea&longs;t A&longs;cent or De&longs;cent, but all be upon one
even Floor, or at lea&longs;t let the A&longs;cents be as
ea&longs;y as may be.
CHAP. III.

That the Parts and Members of a Hou&longs;e are different both in Nature and
Species, and that they are to be adorned in various Manners.

But as the Members or Parts of a Hou&longs;e
are very different one from the other both
in Nature and Species, it may now be proper
to &longs;ay &longs;omething of each, having indeed pur­
po&longs;ely re&longs;erved them for this very Place: For
there are many Parts which it matters very
little whether you make round or &longs;quare, pro­
vided they are fit for the Purpo&longs;es to which they
are intended; but it is not equally indifferent
what Number they are in, and how they are
di&longs;po&longs;ed; and it is nece&longs;&longs;ary that &longs;ome &longs;hould
be larger, as the inner Courts, while &longs;ome re­
quire a &longs;maller Area, as the Chambers and all
the private Apartments.

Some others mu&longs;t be
in a Medium between the others, as Eating­
parlours and the Ve&longs;tibule.

We have already
in another Place given our Thoughts of the
apt Di&longs;po&longs;ition of each Member of a Hou&longs;e,
and as to the re&longs;pective Difference of their
Areas, there is no Occa&longs;ion to &longs;peak here, be­
cau&longs;e they are infinite both from the different
Humours of Men, and the different Ways of
Living in different Places.

The Ancients, be­
fore their Hou&longs;es made either a Portico, or at
lea&longs;t a Porch, not always with &longs;traight Lines,
but &longs;ometimes with curve, after the Manner of
the Theatre.

Next to the Portico lay the Ve&longs;­
tibule, which was almo&longs;t con&longs;tantly circular;
behind that was the Pa&longs;&longs;age into the inner Court,
and tho&longs;e other Parts of the Hou&longs;e which we
have already &longs;poken of in their proper Places,
whereof to enter upon a fre&longs;h De&longs;cription
would make us too prolix.

The Things that
we ought not to omit are the&longs;e.

Where the
Area is round it mu&longs;t be proportioned accord­
ing to the De&longs;ign of the Temple; unle&longs;s there
be this Difference, that here the Height of the
Walls mu&longs;t be greater than in the Temple, for
Rea&longs;ons which you &longs;hall know &longs;hortly.

If it
be quadrangular, then in &longs;ome Particulars it
will differ from tho&longs;e In&longs;tructions which we
have given for &longs;acred Edifices, as al&longs;o for pro­
fane ones of a publick Nature; but yet in
&longs;ome others it will agree with the Council­
chambers and Courts.

According to the ge­
neral Cu&longs;tom of the Ancients, the Breadth of
the Porch was either two thirds of its Length,
or el&longs;e the Length was one whole Breadth and
two thirds more, or el&longs;e the Length was one
whole Breadth with the Addition of two fifths.

To each of the&longs;e Proportions the Ancients &longs;eem
always to have allowed the Height of the Wall to
be equal to its whole Length, and one third more.

By taking the actual Dimen&longs;ion of a great many
Structures, I find that &longs;quare Platforms require
a different Height of Wall where they are to
be covered with vaulted Roofs, from what they
do when their Roof is to be flat: As al&longs;o that
&longs;ome Difference is to be made between the
Proportions of a large Building and tho&longs;e of a
&longs;mall one: Which ari&longs;es from the different In­
terval that there is from the Beholder's Eye,
which mu&longs;t in this Ca&longs;e be con&longs;idered as the
Center, to the extreme Height which it &longs;ur­
veys: But of tho&longs;e Things we &longs;hall treat el&longs;e­
where.

We mu&longs;t Proportion the Areas of our
Apartments to our Roof, and our Roof to the
Length of the Rafters with which it is to be
covered in.

I call that a moderate Roof which
may be &longs;upported by a Piece of Timber of a
moderate Length.

But be&longs;ides the Proportions
which I have already treated of, there are &longs;eve­
ral other proper Dimen&longs;ions and Agreements of
Lines which I &longs;hall here endeavour to explain
as clearly and &longs;uccinctly as po&longs;&longs;ible.

If the
Length of the Platform be twice its Breadth;
then, where the Roof is to be flat, the Height
mu&longs;t be equal to the Breadth; where the Roof
is to be vaulted, a third Part of that Breadth
more mu&longs;t be added.

This may &longs;erve for mid­
dling Buildings: In very large ones, if they are
to have a vaulted Roof, the whole Height mu&longs;t
be one whole Breadth, with the Addition of
one fourth Part; but if the Roof is to be flat
it mu&longs;t be one whole Breadth and two fifths.

If the Length of the Platform be three Times its
Breadth, and the Roof is to be flat, let the
Height be one whole Breath and three quarters,
if the Roof is to be vaulted, let the Height be
one whole Breadth and an half.

If the Length
of the Platform be four Times its Breadth, and
the Roof is to be vaulted, let the Height be
half its Length; and if the Roof is to be flat,
divide the Breadth into four Parts, and give
one and three quarters of tho&longs;e Parts to the
Height.

If the Length be five Times the
Breadth, make the Height the &longs;ame as where
it is four Times, only with the Addition of
one &longs;ixth Part of that Height; and if it is &longs;ix
Times the Breadth, make it as before, adding
not a &longs;ixth as in the former, but a fifth.

If
the Platform be an exact Square with equal
Sides, and the Roof is to be vaulted, let the
Height exceed the Breadth as in the Platform
of three Breadths; but if the Roof is to be flat,
it mu&longs;t not exceed &longs;o much, and in the larger
Platforms, it mu&longs;t not exceed this Breadth
above one fourth Part.

In tho&longs;e Platforms
where the Length exceeds the Breadth only
one ninth Part, let the Height be exceeded by
the Breadth one ninth Part too; but this mu&longs;t
be only in a flat Roof.

When the Length is
to be one whole Breadth and a third, let the
Height be one whole Breadth and a &longs;ixth in flat
Roofs; but in vaulted ones, let the Height be
one whole Breadth and a &longs;ixth of the Length.

When the Length is one Breadth and an Half,
let the Height be one Breadth and a &longs;eventh of
that Breadth, in a flat Roof; but in a vaulted
one, let the Height be one Breadth, and a
&longs;eventh of the Length of the Platform.

If the
Platform con&longs;i&longs;t of Lines whereof one is as
&longs;even, and the other as five, or the Length be
as five and the Breadth as three, or the like,
according as the Nece&longs;&longs;ity of the Place, or Va­
riety of Invention, or the Nature of the Orna­
ments requires; add tho&longs;e two Lines together,
and allow one half of the Amount to the
Height.

I mu&longs;t not here omit one Precaution,
namely, that the Ve&longs;tibule ought never to be
above twice as long as broad, and the Apart­
ments never le&longs;s broad than two thirds of their
Length.

The Platforms which are in Length
three or four Times their Breadth or more, be­
long only to Porticoes, and even they ought
never to be above &longs;ix Times their Breadth.

In
the Wall Apertures are to be left both for
Windows and Doors.

If the Window is broke
in the Wall of the Breadth-line of the Plat­
form, which in its very Nature is &longs;horter than
that of the Length, then there mu&longs;t be only a
&longs;ingle one; and this Window it&longs;elf mu&longs;t either
be higher than it is broad, or el&longs;e on the con­
trary broader than it is high, which la&longs;t Sort is
called a reclining Window.

If the Breadth is
to be like that of the Door, &longs;omewhat le&longs;s than
the Length; then let the Breadth of the clear
Opening be not more than a third, nor le&longs;s than
a fourth Part of the In&longs;ide of the Wall in which
it is made; and let the Re&longs;t or Bottom of the
Window be in Height from the Floor not more
than four ninths of the whole Height, nor le&longs;s
than two.

The Height of the clear Open of
the Window mu&longs;t be one third more than its
Breadth; and this is the Proportion, if the Win­
dow is to be higher than broad; but if the
Window is to be broader then high, than of
the whole in&longs;ide Length of the Wall in which
it is made, you mu&longs;t not allow the Open of the
Window le&longs;s than one half, nor more than two
thirds.

In the &longs;ame Manner its Height too
mu&longs;t be made either half its Breadth, or two
thirds, only it mu&longs;t have two little Columns to
&longs;upport the Tran&longs;om.

If you are to make
Windows in the longer Side, there mu&longs;t be
more of them, and they &longs;hould be in an odd
Number.

I find the Ancients were be&longs;t plea&longs;ed
with three, which were made in the following
Manner: The whole longe&longs;t Side of the Wall
mu&longs;t be divided into never more than &longs;even, nor
le&longs;s than five Parts, of which taking three, in
each of them make a Window, making the
Height of the Open one whole Breadth and
three quarters, or one Breadth and four fifths.

If you would make your Windows more nu­
merous; as they will then partake of the Na­
ture of a Portico, you may borrow the Dimen­
&longs;ions of your Openings from the Rules of the
Portico it&longs;elf, and e&longs;pecially from that of the
Theatre, as we laid them down in their proper
Place.

The Doors mu&longs;t be made after the
Manner of tho&longs;e which we de&longs;cribed for the
Court and Council-chamber.

Let the Dre&longs;s of
the Windows be Corinthian; of the principal
Door, Ionic; of the Doors of the Halls and
Chambers, Doric.

And thus much of the Lines,
as far as they relate to this pre&longs;ent Purpo&longs;e.
CHAP. IV.

With what Paintings, Plants, and Statues, it is proper to adorn the Pave­
ments, Porticoes, Apartments and Gardens of a private Hou&longs;e.

There are &longs;ome other Ornaments ex­
tremely proper for a private Hou&longs;e, by
no means to be omitted in this Place.

The
Ancients &longs;tained the Pavements of their Porti­
coes with Labyrinths, both &longs;quare and circular,
in which the Boys u&longs;ed to exerci&longs;e them&longs;elves.

I have my&longs;elf &longs;een Pavements &longs;tained in Imita­
tion of the Bell-flower-weed, with its Branches
twining about very beautifully.

Other have
paved their Chambers with a Sort of Mo&longs;aic
Work of Marble, in Imitation of Carpets, others
in Imitation of Garlands and Branches of Trees.

It was a very ingenious Invention of O&longs;is, who
&longs;trewed the Pavement at Pergamus with inlaid
Work, in Imitation of the Fragments that lie
&longs;cattered about after Meals; an Ornament not
ill &longs;uited to a Parlour. Agrippa was very right
in making his Floors of common baked Earth.

I, for my Part, hate every Thing that &longs;avours
of Luxury or Profu&longs;ion, and am be&longs;t plea&longs;ed
with tho&longs;e Ornaments which ari&longs;e principally
from the Ingenuity and Beauty of the Contri­
vance.

Upon &longs;ide Walls no Sort of Painting
&longs;hews hand&longs;omer than the Repre&longs;entation of
Columns in Architecture. Titius Cæ&longs;ar adorn­
ed the Walls of the Portico in which he u&longs;ed
to walk, with a Sort of Phœnician Stone &longs;o fine­
ly poli&longs;hed, that it returned the Reflection of
all the Objects like a Looking-gla&longs;s. Antoninus
Caracalla, the Emperor, painted his Portico
with the memorable Exploits and Triumphs of
his Father. Severus did the &longs;ame; but Aga­
thocles painted not his Father's Actions, but his

Accounts the Architects have mo&longs;t frequently

their Apertures they &longs;eldom have exceeded

We are now
to treat of the Fini&longs;hing.

BY the Fini&longs;hing I under&longs;tand a certain

by which the Proportions are mea&longs;ured, where­
of one is the Length, the other the Breadth,
and the other the Height.

THE Rule of the&longs;e Proportions is be&longs;t ga­

Nature herfelf to be mo&longs;t compleat and ad­
mirable; and indeed I am every Day more
and more convinced of the Truth of Pytha­

&longs;i&longs;tently, and with a con&longs;tant Analogy in all

We &longs;hall therefore bor­

greate&longs;t Ma&longs;ters of this Sort of Numbers, and
&longs;rom tho&longs;e particular Things wherein Nature
&longs;hews her&longs;elf mo&longs;t excellent and compleat:
Not that I &longs;hall look any further into the&longs;e

We &longs;hall not therefore pretend to
&longs;ay any thing of Modulation, or the particular

We have already ob­
&longs;erved, that Harmony is an Agreement of &longs;eve­

Of Tones,
&longs;ome are deep, &longs;ome more acute.

The deeper
Tones proceed from a longer String; and the
more acute, from a &longs;horter: And from the mu­
tual Connection of the&longs;e Tones ari&longs;es all the
Variety of Harmony.

This Harmony the An­
cients gathered from interchangeable Concords

as follows: Diapente, or the Fifth, which is

Fourth, called al&longs;o, Se&longs;quitertia: Diapa&longs;on, or
the Eighth, al&longs;o called the double Tone; Dia­
pa&longs;on Diapente, the twelfth or triple Tone, and
Di&longs;diapa&longs;on, the fifteenth or Quadruple.

To
the&longs;e was added the Tonus, which was al&longs;o

The&longs;e &longs;everal Con­
cords, compared with the Strings them&longs;elves,

The Se&longs;qui­
altera was &longs;o called, becau&longs;e the String which
produced it bore the &longs;ame Proportion to that
to which it is compared, as one and an half

In the Se&longs;­
quialtera therefore the longer String mu&longs;t be

THE Se&longs;quitertia is where the longer String
contains the &longs;horter one and one third more:
The longer therefore mu&longs;t be as four, and the
&longs;horter as three.

BUT in that Concord which was called Dia­
pa&longs;on, the Numbers an&longs;wer to one another in
a double Proportion, as two to one, or the
Whole to the Hal&longs;: And in the Triple, they
an&longs;wer as three to one, or as the Whole to one
third of it&longs;elf.

IN the Quadruple the Proportions are as
four to one, or as the Whole to its fourth Part.

LASTLY, all the&longs;e mu&longs;ical Numbers are as

before-mentioned, wherein the long String
compared to the &longs;horter, exceeds it one eighth

OF all the&longs;e Numbers the Architects made
very convenient U&longs;e, taking them &longs;ometimes
two by two, as in planning out their Squares
and open Areas, wherein only two Proporti­

and Breadth; and &longs;ometimes taking them three
by three, as in publick Halls, Council-cham­
bers, and the like; wherein as the Length was

made the Height in a certain harmonious Pro­

CHAP. VI.

Of the Proportions of Numbers in the Mea&longs;uring of Areas, and the Rules for
&longs;ome other Proportions drawn neither from natural Bodies, nor from Harmony.

Of the&longs;e Proportions we are now to treat
more particularly, and fir&longs;t we &longs;hall &longs;ay
&longs;omething of tho&longs;e Areas where only two are
u&longs;ed.

Of Areas, &longs;ome are &longs;hort, &longs;ome long,
and &longs;ome between both.

The &longs;horte&longs;t of all
is the perfect Square, every Side whereof is of
equal Length, all corre&longs;ponding with one an­
other at Right Angles.

The neare&longs;t to this is
the Se&longs;quialtera, and the Se&longs;quitertian al&longs;o may

The&longs;e
three Proportions therefore, which we may al&longs;o
call &longs;imple, are proper for the &longs;maller Plat­
forms.

There are likewi&longs;e three others, which
are proper for middling Platforms: The be&longs;t
of all is the Double, and the next be&longs;t is that
which is formed of the Se&longs;quialtera doubled,
which is produced as follows: Having &longs;et
down the lea&longs;t Number of the Area, as, for

altera, which will make &longs;ix, and then add the
Se&longs;quialtera of this &longs;ix, which will produce
nine.

Thus the Length will exceed the Breadth
in a double Proportion, and one Tone more.

FOR moderate Platforms al&longs;o, we may u&longs;e
that Proportion which ari&longs;es from the Se&longs;qui­
tertian doubled in the &longs;ame Manner as the for­
mer; wherein the Length and Breadth will
be as nine and &longs;ixteen.

HERE the longer Line contains the &longs;horter
twice, excluding one Tone of that &longs;horter

In the longe&longs;t Areas we either add the
Duple to the Se&longs;quialtera, which will produce

Duple, which will make the Proportion as three
to eight; or la&longs;tly make the Lines corre&longs;pond
to each other in a Quadruple Proportion.

We
have now &longs;poke of the &longs;horter Platforms,
wherein the Numbers an&longs;wer to each other
equally, as two to three, or three to four, and
of the Middling, wherein they corre&longs;pond as
two to four, or as four to nine, or as nine to
&longs;ixteen: And la&longs;tly of the longe&longs;t, wherein
the Numbers an&longs;wer in a Triple or Quadruple
Proportion, or as three to eight.

We may
join together or compound all the three Lines
of any Body what&longs;oever, by Means of the&longs;e &longs;e­
veral Number, which are either innate with
Harmony it&longs;elf, or produced from other
Proportions in a certain and regular Me­
thod.

We find in Harmony tho&longs;e Num­

the Triple and the Quadruple.

For In­
&longs;tance, the Duple is formed of the &longs;imple Se&longs;­
quialtera, with the Addition of the Se&longs;quitertia,
in the following Method.

Let the lea&longs;t Num­

this is three, and the Se&longs;quitertia of this Num­

OR el&longs;e the &longs;ame is done in the following

&longs;tance, three; I add one to make it a Se&longs;qui­
tertia, and it becomes four, to which adding a
Se&longs;quialtera, it makes it &longs;ix, which, compared

THE Triple is likewi&longs;e made of the Duple,
and of the Se&longs;quialtera joined together: For

this being doubled, makes four; to which
adding a Se&longs;quialtera, it becomes &longs;ix, which is

OR the &longs;ame Thing is done as follows;
placing the &longs;ame Number of two for the
&longs;maller Number, take the Se&longs;quialtera, and
you will have three, which being doubled,
gives &longs;ix, and &longs;o we &longs;hall have the Triple of

BY Means of the &longs;ame Exten&longs;ions we may
produce the Quadruple, by compounding one

Let the &longs;maller Number here, for In&longs;tance, be

&longs;on, which is as eight to two.

THIS Quadruple may be al&longs;o formed by

what we have &longs;aid above: But for its clearer

of it here.

The Number two, for Example,
by Means of a Se&longs;quialtera is made three, which
by a Se&longs;quitertia becomes four, which four

OR rather in the following Manner.

Let us
take the Number three; this being doubled
makes &longs;ix, to which adding another three, we
have nine, and adding to this a third of it&longs;elf,
it produces twelve, which an&longs;wers to three in a

THE Architects make u&longs;e of all the &longs;everal

indi&longs;tinctly, but in &longs;uch Manner as to be con­
&longs;tantly and every way agreeable to Harmony:
As, for In&longs;tance, in the Elevation of a Room

Triple, but of tho&longs;e only which form the

to the Circum&longs;tances of their Structure.

There
are &longs;ome other natural Proportions for the U&longs;e

The Roots are the Sides of &longs;quare

The fir&longs;t of all Cubes,

it is the mo&longs;t &longs;table and con&longs;tant of all Fi­

But

but only the Source of all others, we may then
&longs;uppo&longs;e the fir&longs;t Number to be the Number

Taking this Number two for the Root,
the Areas will be four, which being rai&longs;ed up

In the
next Place we may con&longs;ider the Line drawn
from one Angle of the Cube to that which is

of the Square into two equal Parts, and this is

What this amounts to
in Numbers is not known: Only it appears

nal of a Cube which is on every Side, as twelve,
Fig. 1.

LASTLY, In a Triangle who&longs;e two &longs;horte&longs;t

the Root of an Area, which is every Way as

will be the Root of an Area, which is as &longs;ix­
teen Fig. 2.

THESE &longs;everal Rules which we have here
&longs;et down for the determining of Proportions,
are the natural and proper Relations of Num­

We are now to &longs;ay &longs;omething of
the Rules of tho&longs;e Proportions, which are not
derived from Harmony or the natural Pro­

for determining the three Relations of an
Apartment; and in order to this we are to
ob&longs;erve, that there are very u&longs;eful Con&longs;idera­
tions in Practice to be drawn from the Mu&longs;i­
cians, Geometers, and even the Arithmeticians,
of each of which we are now to &longs;peak.

The&longs;e
the Philo&longs;ophers call Mediocrates, or Means,
and the Rules for them are many and various;
but there are three particularly which are the
mo&longs;t e&longs;teemed; of all which the Purpo&longs;e is,
that the two Extreams being given, the middle
Mean or Number may corre&longs;pond with them
in a certain detemined Manner, or to u&longs;e
&longs;uch an Expre&longs;&longs;ion, with a regular Affinity.

Our Bu&longs;ine&longs;s, in this Enquiry, is to con&longs;ider
three Terms, whereof the two mo&longs;t remote
are one the greate&longs;t, and the other the lea&longs;t;
the third or mean Number mu&longs;t an&longs;wer to
the&longs;e other two in a ju&longs;t Relation or proporti­
onate Interval, which Interval is the equal re­
lative Di&longs;tance which this Number &longs;tands from
the other two.

Of the three Methods mo&longs;t
approved by the Philo&longs;ophers for finding this
Mean, that which is called the arithmetical is
the mo&longs;t ea&longs;y, and is as follows.

Taking the
two extreme Numbers, as for In&longs;tance, eight
for the greate&longs;t, and four for the lea&longs;t, you add
them together, which produce twelve, which
twelve being divided in two equal Parts, gives
us &longs;ix.

THIS Number &longs;ix the Arithmeticians &longs;ay, is
the Mean, which &longs;tanding between four and
eight, is at an equal Di&longs;tance from each of
them.

THE next Mean is that which is called the
Geometrical, and is taken thus.

Let the &longs;mall­
e&longs;t Number, for Example, four, be multiplied
by the greate&longs;t, which we &longs;hall &longs;uppo&longs;e to be
nine; the Multiplication will produce 36:
The Root of which Sum as it is called, or the
Number of its Side being multiplied by it&longs;elf
mu&longs;t al&longs;o produce 36. The Root therefore
will be &longs;ix, which multiplied by it&longs;elf is 36,
and this Number &longs;ix, is the Mean.

THIS geometrical Mean is very difficult to
find by Numbers, but it is very clear by Lines;
but of tho&longs;e it is not my Bu&longs;ine&longs;s to &longs;peak
here.

The third Mean, which is called the
Mu&longs;ical, is &longs;omewhat more difficult to work
than the Arithmetical; but, however, may be
very well performed by Numbers.

In this the
Proportion between the lea&longs;t Term and the
greate&longs;t, mu&longs;t be the &longs;ame as the Di&longs;tance be­
tween the lea&longs;t and the Mean, and between the
Mean and the greate&longs;t, as in the following Ex­
ample.

Of the two given Numbers, let the
lea&longs;t be thirty, and the greate&longs;t &longs;ixty, which is
ju&longs;t the Double of the other.

I take &longs;uch
Numbers as cannot be le&longs;s to be double, and
the&longs;e are one, for the lea&longs;t, and two, for the
greate&longs;t, which added together make three.

I
then divide the whole Interval which was be­
tween the greate&longs;t Number, which was &longs;ixty,
and the lea&longs;t, which was thirty, into three
Parts, each of which Parts therefore will be
ten, and one of the&longs;e three Parts I add to the
lea&longs;t Number, which will make it forty; and
this will be the mu&longs;ical Mean de&longs;ired.

AND this mean Number forty will be di&longs;­
tant from the greate&longs;t Number ju&longs;t double the
Interval which the Number of the Mean is
di&longs;tant from the lea&longs;t Number; and the Con­
dition was, that the greate&longs;t Number &longs;hould
bear that Portion to the lea&longs;t.

By the Help of
the&longs;e Mediocrites the Architects have di&longs;cover­
ed many excellent Things, as well with Rela­
tion to the whole Structure, as to its &longs;everal
Parts; which we have not Time here to par­
ticularize.

But the mo&longs;t common U&longs;e they
have made of the&longs;e Mediocrities, has been how­

CHAP. VII.
Of the Invention of Columns, their Dimen&longs;ions and Collocation.

It will not be unplea&longs;ant to con&longs;ider &longs;ome
further Particulars relating to the three
Sorts of Columns which the Ancients invent­
ed, in three different Points of Time: And it
is not at all improbable, that they borrowed the
Proportions of their Columns from that of the
Members of the human Body.

Thus they
found that from one Side of a Man to the
other was a &longs;ixth Part of his Height, and that
from the Navel to the Reins was a tenth.

From
this Ob&longs;ervation the Interpreters of our &longs;acred
Books, are of Opinion, that Noah's Ark for
the Flood was built according to the Propor­
tions of the human Body.

By the &longs;ame Pro­
portions we may rea&longs;onably conjecture, that the
Ancients erected their Columns, making the
Height in &longs;ome &longs;ix Times, and in others ten
Times, the Diameter of the Bottom of the
Sha&longs;t.

But from that natural In&longs;tinct or Sen&longs;e
in the Mind by which, as we have already ob­
&longs;erved, we judge of Beauty and Gracefulne&longs;s,
they found, that one of the&longs;e was too thick and
the other too &longs;light; for which Rea&longs;on they
altered them both, rightly &longs;uppo&longs;ing that the
Truth mu&longs;t lie in &longs;ome Medium between the&longs;e
two vitious Extremes.

Accordingly, with the
Help of the Rules of the Arithmeticians, they
joined their two Numbers together, and divid­
ed the Total in half, and then they found that
the mean Number between &longs;ix and ten was
eight: Whereupon they made the Height of
their Column eight Times the Diameter of the
Bottom of the Shaft; and this they called the
Ionic.

They al&longs;o formed their Doric Column,
which is proper for Buildings of greater Solidi­
ty, by the &longs;ame Rules.

For Example, they
joined the &longs;maller Number before-mentioned,
which was &longs;ix, with the Ionic mean, which was
eight, whereof the Total was fourteen; this
Total they divided into two equal Parts, and
this gave them the Number &longs;even, which they
took for their Doric Column, making its Length
&longs;even Times the Diameter of the Bottom of the
Shaft.

La&longs;tly, they made their thinne&longs;t Order,
which they called the Corinthian, from the Ionic
mean Number joined to the greate&longs;t of the for­
mer Numbers, and &longs;o taking the Half as
before; for the Ionic mean Number was eight,
and the greate&longs;t Number was ten, which add­
ed together made eighteen, the Half whereof
was nine, whence they made the Height of
their Corinthian Column nine Times the Dia­
meter of the Bottom of its Shaft, as they did
the Ionic eight, and the Doric &longs;even: Of which
we need &longs;ay no more in this Place.

We are
now to &longs;ay &longs;omething of the Collocation, which
relates to the Situation of the &longs;everal Parts;
and this is much ea&longs;ier to conceive where it is
ill done, than it is to lay down exact Rules for
the doing it: Becau&longs;e indeed it is chiefly to be
referred to the natural Judgment which we
have formerly ob&longs;erved to be innate in the
Mind of Man, though it may in &longs;ome Mea­
&longs;ure be derived from the foregoing Rules for
the Fini&longs;hing.

However, we &longs;hall ju&longs;t men­
tion a few general Remarks upon this Head.

The very &longs;malle&longs;t Parts or Members of the
Work, if they are &longs;et in their right Places, add
to the Beauty of the whole; if they are placed
in mean or improper Situations, though excel­
lent in them&longs;elves, they become mean.

We
&longs;ee the very &longs;ame Thing in the Works of Na­
ture: As for In&longs;tance, if a Dog had one Ear
like that of an A&longs;s, or if a Man had one Foot
bigger than the other, or one Hand very large,
and the other very &longs;mall, we &longs;hould immedi­
ately pronounce &longs;uch a one deformed; or to
&longs;ee even an Hor&longs;e with one Eye grey, and the
other black, is very offen&longs;ive: So agreeable it
is to Nature, that the Members on the right
Side &longs;hould exactly an&longs;wer the left: Wherefore
the very fir&longs;t Thing we are to take Care of
mu&longs;t be, that every Part, even the mo&longs;t Incon­
&longs;iderable, lie duly to the Level and Plum-line,
and be di&longs;po&longs;ed with an exact Corre&longs;pondence
as to the Number, Form and Appearance; &longs;o
that the Right may an&longs;wer to the Left, the
High to the Low, the Similar to the Similar, &longs;o
as to form a corre&longs;pondent Ornament in that
Body whereof they are Parts.

Even Statues,
Pictures, or any other Ornaments of that Sort
with which we embelli&longs;h our Work, mu&longs;t be &longs;o
di&longs;po&longs;ed as to &longs;eem to have &longs;prung up naturally
in their propere&longs;t Places, and to be Twins.

The
Ancients were &longs;o punctual in this mutual Cor­
re&longs;pondence of the Parts, that even in fixing
up their Scantlings of Marble, they u&longs;ed to
make them an&longs;wer each other exactly to a
Size, Quality, Angles, Situation and Colour:
And e&longs;pecially in tho&longs;e mo&longs;t beautiful Orna­
ments, Statues, wherein the Ancients were &longs;uch
great Ma&longs;ters, and in which I &longs;o much admire
the Excellence of Art, they were careful in fix­
ing them up, as well on Pediments of their
Temples, as el&longs;ewhere, that tho&longs;e on one Side
&longs;hould not differ from tho&longs;e on the other, in
the &longs;malle&longs;t Particular either of De&longs;ign or Ma­
terial.

We &longs;ee Statues of two or four Hor&longs;es,
and of their Drivers and Lookers on &longs;o exact­
ly like to each other, that Art in them may be
&longs;aid to have exceeded Nature, in who&longs;e Works
we hardly ever &longs;ee one Feature &longs;o exactly like
the other.

Thus we have &longs;hewn what is Beauty,
and wherein it con&longs;i&longs;ts, and with what Num­
bers and Fini&longs;hing the Ancients u&longs;ed to erect
their Structures.
CHAP. VIII.

Some &longs;hort, but general Ob&longs;ervations which may be looked upon as Laws in the
Bu&longs;ine&longs;s of Building and Ornament.

I shall here put together &longs;ome &longs;hort and ge­
neral Admonitions, which are ab&longs;olutely
nece&longs;&longs;ary to be ob&longs;erved as &longs;o many Laws, as
well in Point of Ornament or Embelli&longs;hment,
as in all the other Parts of Architecture.

And
this may &longs;erve to acquit us of the Promi&longs;e
which we made of taking a &longs;hort Review of
the whole Work by Way of Epilogue.

Fir&longs;t
therefore, as we laid it down for a Rule at the
Beginning, that all Errors which any Ways de­
form the Structure were to be avoided princi­
pally: We will now &longs;peak in the fir&longs;t Place of
&longs;uch Errors, and e&longs;pecially of the greate&longs;t.

Er­
rors ari&longs;e either from the Judgement, and lie
either in the De&longs;ign or Election; or from the
Hand, and lie in the Workmen's Execution.

The Errors of the Judgment are both in Time
and in their Nature of much the greate&longs;t Im­
portance, and when committed, le&longs;s capable of
being remedied.

With the&longs;e therefore we &longs;hall
begin.

The fir&longs;t Error is to chu&longs;e for your
Structure a Region which is unhealthy, not
peaceable, barren, unfortunate, melancholy, or
afflicted with Calamities, either apparent or
concealed.

The next Errors to this are chu&longs;­
ing a Platform not proper or convenient; add­
ing one Member to another, without con&longs;tant
Regard to the Accommodation of the Inhabi­
tants, and not providing fit and &longs;uitable Con­
veniencies for every Rank and Degree of them,
as well Ma&longs;ters as Servants, Citizens as Ru&longs;­
ticks, Inmates as Vi&longs;itants: Making your Build­
ing either too large and &longs;pacious, or too &longs;mall
and narrow; too open and naked, or too much
&longs;hut in and confined; too much crowded, or
too rambling with too many Apartments, or
too few: If there be a Want of Rooms where
you may &longs;ecure your&longs;elf again&longs;t exce&longs;&longs;ive Heats,
or exce&longs;&longs;ive Colds, of Places where you may
exerci&longs;e and divert your&longs;elf when you are in
Health, and of others where you may be &longs;uf­
ficiently &longs;heltered again&longs;t any Inclemency of
Air when you are &longs;ick: To which add the
Structures not being &longs;ufficiently &longs;trong, and as
we may &longs;ay, fortified to be &longs;afe again&longs;t any &longs;ud­
den Attack: If the Wall be either &longs;o &longs;light as
not to be &longs;ufficiently &longs;trong to &longs;upport it&longs;elf
and the Roof, or much thicker than Nece&longs;&longs;ity
requires, if the different Roofs be&longs;patter each
other with their Waters, or throw them again&longs;t
any Part of the Wall, or near the Entrances:
If they be either too low, or too high: If your
Windows be too wide, and admit unwhole­
&longs;ome Winds, noxious Dews, or too much burn­
ing Sun; or, on the other Hand, if they be &longs;o
narrow as to occa&longs;ion a melancholy Gloom:
If they break into any of the Ribs of the Build­
ing: If the Pa&longs;&longs;ages are any Ways ob&longs;tructed,
or lead us to any Object that is offen&longs;ive: Or,
in &longs;hort, if any of tho&longs;e other In&longs;tructions are
neglected, which we have given in the preced­
ing Books.

Among the Errors in Ornament,
the Principal, in Architecture as in Nature, is
making any Thing prepo&longs;terous, maimed, ex­
ce&longs;&longs;ive, or any other Ways un&longs;ightly: For if
the&longs;e Things are reckoned defective and mon­
&longs;trous in Nature her&longs;elf, what mu&longs;t we &longs;ay of
an Architect that throws the Parts of his Struc­
tures into &longs;uch improper Forms?

And as the
Parts whereof tho&longs;e Forms con&longs;i&longs;t, are Lines,
Angles, Exten&longs;ion, and the like, it is certainly
true, that there can be no Error or Deformity
more ab&longs;urd and &longs;hocking, than the mixing
together either Angles or Lines, or Superficies
which are not in Number, Size and Situation
equal to each other, and which are not blended
together with the greate&longs;t Care and Accuracy.

And indeed who can avoid blaming a Man ex­
tremely, that without being forced to it by any
Manner of Nece&longs;&longs;ity, draws his Wall crooked
and askew, winding this way and that like a
Worm crawling upon the Ground, without
any Rule or Method, with one Side long, and
another &longs;hort, without any Equality of Angles,
or the lea&longs;t Connection with Regard to each
other; making his Platform with an obtu&longs;e
Angle on one Side, and an acute one on the
other, and doing every Thing with Confu&longs;ion,
Ab&longs;urdity and at a Venture: It is another
great Error to have rai&longs;ed your Structure in
&longs;uch a Manner, that, though indeed with Re­
lation to its Platform, it is not ami&longs;s, yet, not­
with&longs;tanding it may be in very great Want of
Ornament, it may be utterly incapable of any
Sort of Embelli&longs;hment as if all you con&longs;ulted
in rai&longs;ing your Wall, was to &longs;u&longs;tain the Roof,
not leaving any Space where you can after­
wards conveniently or di&longs;tinctly add either the
Dignity of Columns, the Embelli&longs;hment of Sta­
tues, the Maje&longs;ty of Picture, or the Delicacy
of any Incru&longs;tation.

An Error of much the
&longs;ame Nature as this is, the Building with &longs;o
little Con&longs;ideration, that though the &longs;ame Ex­
pence might make our Structure beautiful and
graceful, yet we neglect the Pains and Con­
trivance of effecting it: For it is undeniable
that there may be in the mere Form or Figure
of a Building, an innate Excellence and Beau­
ty, which &longs;trikes and delights the Mind, and
is immediately perceived where it is, as much
as it is mi&longs;&longs;ed where it is not; for, indeed, the
Eye is naturally a Judge and Lover of Beauty
and Gracefulne&longs;s, and is very critical and hard
to plea&longs;e in it; neither can I give any Account
why it &longs;hould always happen, that we &longs;hould
be much more offended at what is wanting,
than ready to commend what is done well;
for &longs;till we are continually thinking what fur­
ther might be added to make the Object &longs;till
more &longs;plendid, and are naturally di&longs;plea&longs;ed if
any thing is omitted, which the mo&longs;t accurate,
ingenious, and diligent Arti&longs;t might po&longs;&longs;ibly
have procured: So that indeed we are often at
a Lo&longs;s to &longs;ay what it is offends us, unle&longs;s it be
that there is not wherewithal fully to &longs;atisfy our
immoderate De&longs;ire of Perfection.

This being
the true State of the Ca&longs;e, we &longs;hould certainly
endeavour, as much as in us lies, by the great­
e&longs;t Study and Care, to make whatever Struc­
ture we rai&longs;e as hand&longs;ome, and as compleatly
adorned as po&longs;&longs;ibly, e&longs;pecially if it be &longs;uch a
one as every body expects to &longs;ee in the utmo&longs;t
Perfection, as, for In&longs;tance, a publick Structure,
and particularly a &longs;acred one, which no Man
can bear to &longs;ee naked of Ornament.

It is an­
other Error to apply the Ornaments peculiar to
a publick Structure, to a private one; or, on
the other Hand, tho&longs;e peculiar to private Edi­
fices to one of a publick Nature: E&longs;pecially if
&longs;uch Ornaments are any thing petty, or not
durable, as, for In&longs;tance, to di&longs;h up a publick
Structure with &longs;light or paultry Painting; for
every Thing u&longs;ed about a publick Edifice ought,
if po&longs;&longs;ible, to be eternal.

It is another gro&longs;s
Error, which we &longs;ee &longs;ome ridiculous People
run into, who e'er they have well begun their
Building, fall to painting it, and decking it with
Statues and other Embelli&longs;hments without
Number; all which are &longs;ure to be &longs;poiled and
demoli&longs;hed before the Building is fini&longs;hed.

We &longs;hould erect our Building naked, and let
it be quite compleated before we begin to
dre&longs;s it with Ornaments, which &longs;hould always
be our la&longs;t Work, being be&longs;t done at lea&longs;ure,
when we can do it without any Impediment,
and can take the Advantage of &longs;uch Opportu­
nities as may offer for that Purpo&longs;e.

I would
have the Ornaments which you affix to your
Structure, to be the Work of various Hands,
and tho&longs;e moderate Ma&longs;ters; but if you can
procure any rare Pieces of greater Excellence
and Perfection, Statues and Pictuaes like tho&longs;e
of a Phidias or a Zeuxis, let them be fixed only
in Places of peculiar Dignity and Honour.

I
cannot commend Dejoces the King of Media,
who encompa&longs;&longs;ed his City of Ecbatana with
&longs;even Walls, and made each of them of diffe­
rent Colours, one Purple, another Blue, another
gilt with Silver, and one even with Gold; nor can
I help blaming Caligula, who made his Stable
of Marble, and the Manger of Ivory.

All that
Nero built was covered with Gold and enriched
with Gems. Heliogabalus was &longs;till more ex­
travagantly profu&longs;e, for he paved his Apart­
ments with Gold, and grieved that he could
not do it with Amber.

Contempt is the be&longs;t
Reward for the&longs;e wild Prodigals who are o&longs;­
tentatious of &longs;uch Vain-glories, or rather Fol­
lies, and who are thus profu&longs;e of the Labours
and Sweat of Mankind, about Things which
are of no Manner of U&longs;e or Advantage to the
main Structure, nor capable of rai&longs;ing the lea&longs;t
Admiration either for Ingenuity or Contrivance.

I THEREFORE over and over again advi&longs;e you
to avoid the&longs;e Errors; and before you begin
your Work, thoroughly con&longs;ider the whole
De&longs;ign your &longs;elf, and take the Advice of Men
of Skill upon it; be &longs;ure to have a compleat
Model of the Whole, by which examine every
minute Part of your future Structure eight,
nine, ten Times over, and again, after different
Intermi&longs;&longs;ions of Times; till there be not the
lea&longs;t Member from the Foundation to the
Roof of your whole Building, within or without,
great or &longs;mall, but what you have throughly
and long weighed and con&longs;idered, and deter­
mined of what Materials it &longs;hall be made,
where placed, in what Order and Proportions,
and to what it &longs;hall an&longs;wer and bear Relation.
CHAP. IX.

The Bu&longs;ine&longs;s and Duty of a good Architect, and wherein the Excellence of the
Ornaments con&longs;i&longs;ts.

A Prudent Architect will proceed in the
Method which we have been ju&longs;t laying
down.

He will never &longs;et about his Work without
proper Caution and Advice.

He will &longs;tudy the
Nature and Strength of the Soil where he is to
build, and ob&longs;erve, as well from a Survey of
Structures in the Neighbourhood, as from the
Practice and U&longs;e of the Inhabitants, what Ma­
terials, what Sort of Stone, Sand, Lime or
Timber, whether found on the Place, or
brought from other Parts, will be&longs;t &longs;tand again&longs;t
the Injuries of the Weather.

He will &longs;et
out the exact Breadth and Depth of the Foun­
dations, and of the Ba&longs;ement of the whole
Wall, and take an Account of every Thing
that is nece&longs;&longs;ary for the Building, whether for
the outward Coat or the filling up, for the Li­
gatures, the Ribs, or the Apertures, the Roof,
the Incru&longs;tation, for Pavements abroad, or
Floors within; he will direct which Way,
and by what Method every thing &longs;uperfluous,
noxious or offen&longs;ive &longs;hall be carried off by
Drains for conveying away the rain Water,
and keeping the Foundations dry, and by pro­
per Defences again&longs;t any moi&longs;t Vapours, or
even again&longs;t any unexpected Floods or Vio­
lence from Winds or Storms.

In a Word,
he will give Directions for every &longs;ingle Part,
and not &longs;uffer any thing to e&longs;cape his Notice
and Decree.

And tho' all the&longs;e Particulars &longs;eem
chiefly to relate to Convenience and Stability,
yet they carry this along with them, that if
neglected they de&longs;troy all the Beauty and Or­
nament of the Edifice.

Now the Rules which
give the Ornaments them&longs;elves their main Ex­
cellence, are as follows.

Fir&longs;t all your Orna­
ments mu&longs;t be exactly regular, and perfectly
di&longs;tinct, and without Confu&longs;ion: Your Em­
belli&longs;hments mu&longs;t not be too much crowded
together or &longs;cattered as it were under Foot, or
thrown on in Heaps, but &longs;o aptly and neatly
di&longs;tributed, that whoever &longs;hould go about to
alter their Situation, &longs;hould be &longs;en&longs;ible that
he de&longs;troyed the whole Beauty and Delicacy
of the Work.

There is no Part what&longs;oever
but what the Arti&longs;t ought to adorn; but there
is no Occa&longs;ion that all &longs;hould be adorned
equally, or that every thing &longs;hould be enriched
with equal Expence; for indeed I would not
have the Merit of the Work con&longs;i&longs;t &longs;o much
in Plenty as in Variety.

Let the Builder fix
his riche&longs;t Ornaments in the principal Places;
tho&longs;e of a middling Sort, in Places of le&longs;s Note,
and the meane&longs;t in the meane&longs;t.

And here
he &longs;hould be particularly careful, not to mix
what is rich with any thing trifling, nothing
little with what is great, nor to &longs;et any thing
too large or high in narrow or clo&longs;e Places;
tho' things which are not equal to each other
in Dignity, nor alike even in Species, may very
well be placed together, &longs;o it be done artfully
and ingeniou&longs;ly, and in &longs;uch a Manner, that
as the one appears &longs;olemn and maje&longs;tick, the
other may &longs;hew chearful and plea&longs;ant, and that
they may not only unite their different Beau­
ties for the Embelli&longs;hment of the Structure,
but al&longs;o &longs;eem as if the one without the other
had been imperfect; nor may it be ami&longs;s in
&longs;ome certain Places to intermix &longs;omewhat even
of a coar&longs;e Sort, that what is noble may re­
ceive a yet further Addition from the Com­
pari&longs;on: Always be &longs;ure never to make a Con­
fu&longs;ion of the Orders, which will happen if you
mix the Doric Members with the Corinthian,
as I ob&longs;erved before, or the Corinthian with
the Ionic, or the like.

Let every Order have
its own regular Members, and tho&longs;e all in their
proper Places, that nothing may appear per­
plexed or broken.

Let &longs;uch Ornaments as are
proper to the Middle be placed in the Middle,
and let tho&longs;e which are at equal Di&longs;tances on
each Side, be proportioned exactly alike.

In
&longs;hort, let every thing be mea&longs;ured, and put to­
gether with the greate&longs;t Exactne&longs;s of Lines and
Angles, that the Beholder's Eye may have a
clear and di&longs;tinct View along the Cornices, be­
tween the Columns on the In&longs;ide and without,
receiving every Moment fre&longs;h Delight from the
Variety he meets with, in&longs;omuch, that after the
mo&longs;t careful and even repeated Views, he &longs;hall
not be able to depart without once more turn­
ing back to take another Look, nor, upon the
mo&longs;t critical Examination, be able in any Part
of the whole Structure to find one Thing un­
equal, incongruous, out of Proportion, or not
conducive to the general Beauty of the Whole.

All the&longs;e Particulars you mu&longs;t provide for by
means of your Model; and from thence too
you &longs;hould before-hand con&longs;ider not only what
the Building is that you are to erect, but al&longs;o
get together all the Materials you &longs;hall want
for the Execution, that when you have begun
your Work you may not be at a Lo&longs;s, or
change or &longs;uper&longs;ede your De&longs;ign: but having
before-hand made Provi&longs;ion of every Thing that
you &longs;hall want, you may be able to keep your
Workmen con&longs;tantly &longs;upplied with all their Ma­
terials.

The&longs;e are the Things which the Archi­
tect is to take care of with the greate&longs;t Dili­
gence and Judgement.

The Errors which
may happen in the manual Execution of the
Work, need not be repeated here; but only
the Workmen &longs;hould be well looked after, to
&longs;ee that they work exactly by their Square,
Level and Plumb-line; that they do their
Bu&longs;ine&longs;s at the proper Sea&longs;ons, take proper Sea­
&longs;ons to let their Work re&longs;t, and at proper Sea­
&longs;ons go to it again; that they u&longs;e good Stuff,
&longs;ound, unmixed, &longs;olid, &longs;trong, and &longs;uitable to
the Work, and that they u&longs;e it in proper Places,
and fini&longs;h every Thing according to their Mo­
del.
CHAP. X.

What it is that an Architect ought principally to con&longs;ider, and what Sciences
he ought to be acquainted with.

But to the Intent that the Architect may
come off worthily and honourably in
preparing, ordering and accompli&longs;hing all
the&longs;e Things, there are &longs;ome nece&longs;&longs;ary Ad­
monitions, which he &longs;hould by no means ne­
glect.

And fir&longs;t he ought to con&longs;ider well
what Weight he is going to take upon his
Shoulders, what it is that he profe&longs;&longs;es, what
Manner of Man he would be thought, how
great a Bu&longs;ine&longs;s he undertakes, how much Ap­
plau&longs;e, Profit, Favour and Fame among Po&longs;­
terity he will gain when he executes his Work
as he ought, and on the contrary, if he goes
about any thing ignorantly, unadvi&longs;edly, or in­
con&longs;iderately, to how much Di&longs;grace, to how
much Indignation he expo&longs;es him&longs;elf, what a
clear, manife&longs;t and everla&longs;ting Te&longs;timony he
gives Mankind of his Folly and Indi&longs;cretion.

Doubtle&longs;s Architecture is a very noble Science,
not fit for every Head.

He ought to be a Man
of a fine Genius, of a great Application, of the
be&longs;t Education, of thorough Experience, and
e&longs;pecially of &longs;trong Sen&longs;e and &longs;ound Judge­
ment, that pre&longs;umes to declare him&longs;elf an
Architect.

It is the Bu&longs;ine&longs;s of Architecture,
and indeed its highe&longs;t Prai&longs;e, to judge rightly
what is fit and decent: For though Building is
a Matter of Nece&longs;&longs;ity, yet convenient Building
is both of Nece&longs;&longs;ity and Utility too: But to
build in &longs;uch a Manner, that the Generous &longs;hall
commend you, and the Frugal not blame you,
is the Work only of a prudent, wi&longs;e and learn­
ed Architect.

To run up any thing that is
immediately nece&longs;&longs;ary for any particular Pur­
po&longs;e, and about which there is no doubt of
what Sort it &longs;hould be, or of the Ability of
the Owner to afford it, is not &longs;o much the
Bu&longs;ine&longs;s of an Architect, as of a common
Workman: But to rai&longs;e an Edifice which is to
be compleat in every Part, and to con&longs;ider and
provide before-hand every Thing nece&longs;&longs;ary for
&longs;uch a Work, is the Bu&longs;ine&longs;s only of that ex­
ten&longs;ive Genius which I have de&longs;cribed above:
For indeed his Invention mu&longs;t be owing to his
Wit, his Knowledge, to Experience, his Choice
to Judgment, his Compo&longs;ition to Study, and
the Completion of his Work to his Perfection
in his Art; of all which Qualifications I take
the Foundation to be Prudence and mature
Deliberation.

As to the other Virtues, Hu­
manity, Benevolence, Mode&longs;ty, Probity; I do
not require them more in the Architect, than
I do in every other Man, let him profe&longs;s what
Art he will: For indeed without them I do
not think any one worthy to be deemed a Man:
But above all Things he &longs;hould avoid Levity,
Ob&longs;tinacy, O&longs;tentation, Intemperance, and all
tho&longs;e other Vices which may lo&longs;e him the good
Will of his Fellow-Citizens, and make him
odious to the World.

La&longs;tly, in the Study of
his Art I would have him follow the Example
of tho&longs;e that apply them&longs;elves to Letters: For
no Man thinks him&longs;elf &longs;ufficiently learned in
any Science, unle&longs;s he has read and examined
all the Authors, as well bad as good that have
wrote in that Science which he is pur&longs;uing.

In
the &longs;ame Manner I would have the Architect
diligently con&longs;ider all the Buildings that have
any tolerable Reputation; and not only &longs;o, but
take them down in Lines and Numbers, nay,
make De&longs;igns and Models of them, and by
means of tho&longs;e, con&longs;ider and examine the Or­
der, Situation, Sort and Number of every Part
which others have employed, e&longs;pecially &longs;uch as
have done any thing very great and excellent,
whom we may rea&longs;onably &longs;uppo&longs;e to have
been Men of very great Note, when they were
intru&longs;ted with the Direction of &longs;o great an Ex­
pence.

Not that I would have him admire a
Structure merely for being huge, and imagine
that to be a &longs;ufficient Beauty; but let him
principally enquire in every Building what
there is particularly artful and excellent for
Contrivance or Invention, and gain a Habit of
being plea&longs;ed with nothing but what is really
elegant and prai&longs;e-worthy for the De&longs;ign: And
where-ever he finds any thing noble, let him
make u&longs;e of it, or imitate it in his own Per­
formances; and when he &longs;ees any thing well
done, that is capable of being &longs;till further im­
proved and made delicate, let him &longs;tudy to
bring it to Perfection in his own Works; and
when he meets with any De&longs;ign that is only
not ab&longs;olutely bad, let him try in his own
Things to work it if po&longs;&longs;ible into &longs;omething
excellent.

Thus by a continued and nice Ex­
amination of the be&longs;t Productions, &longs;till con­
&longs;idering what Improvements might be made in
every thing that he &longs;ees, he may &longs;o exerci&longs;e
and &longs;harpen his own Invention, as to collect
into his own Works not only all the Beauties
which are di&longs;per&longs;ed up and down in tho&longs;e of
other Men, but even tho&longs;e which lie in a Man­
ner concealed in the mo&longs;t hidden Rece&longs;&longs;es of
Nature, to his own immortal Reputation.

Not
&longs;atisfied with this, he &longs;hould al&longs;o have an Am­
bition to produce &longs;omething admirable, which
may be entirely of his own Invention; like him,
for In&longs;tance, who built a Temple without u&longs;ing
one iron Tool in it; or him that brought the
Colo&longs;&longs;us to Rome, &longs;u&longs;pended all the Way up­
right, in which Work we may ju&longs;t mention
that he employed no le&longs;s than four-and-twenty
Elephants; or like an Arti&longs;t that in only &longs;eem­
ingly working a common Quarry of Stone,
&longs;hould cut it out into a Labyrinth, a Temple,
or &longs;ome other u&longs;eful Structure, to the Surpri&longs;e
of all Mankind.

We are told that Nero u&longs;ed
to employ miraculous Architects, who never
thought of any Invention, but what it was al­
mo&longs;t impo&longs;&longs;ible for the Skill of Man to reduce
to practice.

Such Geniu&longs;&longs;es I can by no mean
approve of; for, indeed, I would have the
Architect always appear to have con&longs;ulted Ne­
ce&longs;&longs;ity and Convenience in the fir&longs;t Place, even
tho' at the very &longs;ame Time his principal Care
has been Ornament.

If he can make a hand­
&longs;ome Mixture of the noble Orders of the An­
cients, with any of the new Inventions of the

BOOK X. CHAP. I.

Since in the Remainder of this

Of the Defects in Buildings, as well

We

What are

But to proceed briefly with

nels of Water were entirely &longs;topt.

In ancient
Times the Nile having once &longs;welled higher

the Mud, they left a great Number of different
Animals, which as the Ground became dry,
rotted and infected the Air with a dreadful

for it to run off, it renders the Air unwhole­
&longs;ome and infectious.

Moreover, towards the
northern Parts of Africa, and al&longs;o in Æthiopia,
it never Rains; &longs;o that the Lakes are often

Again&longs;t the&longs;e Inconveni­
encies, both the Remedies u&longs;ed by Hercules are

It may al&longs;o be of Ser­
vice to fill up the Place with Stones, Earth or

&longs;tanding Water with River-&longs;and, we &longs;hall &longs;hew

The Country of Alexandria is &longs;aid to

Thus we are in­
&longs;tructed by Nature what is proper to be done,
and that where the Ground is mar&longs;hy, we

Of which we &longs;hall &longs;ay
no more in this Place.
CHAP. II.
That Water is the mo&longs;t nece&longs;&longs;ary Thing of all, and of its various Sorts.

We are now to take care that nothing
be wanting, which may be nece&longs;&longs;ary
for our U&longs;e.

What Things are nece&longs;&longs;ary I
&longs;hall not wa&longs;te much Time in recounting, be­
cau&longs;e they are manife&longs;t, as Food, Raiment,
Shelter, and, above all Things, Water. Thales
the Mile&longs;ian affirmed, that Water was the fir&longs;t
Principle of all Things, and even of Commu­
nities among Men. Ari&longs;tobulus &longs;ays, that he
&longs;aw above a thou&longs;and Towns left quite de&longs;art,
becau&longs;e the River Indus had turned his Cour&longs;e
another Way.

I own it to be my Opinion,
that Water is to Animals the Source of natural
Heat and the Nouri&longs;her of Life; not to men­
tion its Con&longs;equence to Plants, and to every
Thing el&longs;e which is intended for the U&longs;e of
Mankind; to all which I imagine it to be &longs;o
ab&longs;olutely nece&longs;&longs;ary, that, without Water, no­
thing which grows or is nouri&longs;hed in the Earth
would be capable even of exi&longs;ting.

In the
Country, along the River Euphrates, the People
do not &longs;uffer their Cattle to feed as long as
they would, for fear of their growing too fat
in Pa&longs;tures too luxurious, occa&longs;ioned, as is &longs;up­
po&longs;ed, by the Exuberance of Moi&longs;ture: And
&longs;ome believe, that &longs;uch huge Bodies as Whales
are produced in the Sea, becau&longs;e of the great
Abundance of Nouri&longs;hment which is afforded
by Water. Xenophon tells us, that the Kings
of Sparta were allowed, by way of Dignity,
to have a Lake of Water before the Doors of
their Hou&longs;es.

Water is u&longs;ed by us in the Ce­
remonies of our Nuptials, Sacrifices, and almo&longs;t
all other &longs;acred Rites, according to the Prac­
tice of our Fore-fathers; all which &longs;hews what
a high E&longs;teem ancient Times had of Water.

But indeed who can deny the great U&longs;e and
Service which it is of to Mankind, in&longs;omuch
that it is always thought to be deficient, where
there is not a very large Abundance of it for all
Manner of Occa&longs;ions.

With this great Ne­
ce&longs;&longs;ary therefore, we &longs;hall here begin, &longs;ince,
according to the old Saying, we want it whe­
ther &longs;ick or well.

The Me&longs;&longs;agetœ, a Nation
of Scythia, made their Country abound in Wa­
ter by opening the River Aragus in &longs;everal
Places.

The Tygris and Euphrates were brought
by Labour to Babylon, which was built origi­
nally in a dry Place.

Queen Semiramis cut a
Pa&longs;&longs;age through a high Hill for the Space of
five-and-twenty Furlongs to make Way for a
Canal, fifteen Foot broad, by which &longs;he brought

An Arabian
King brought Water from the Chorus, a River
of Arabia, into that droughty De&longs;art where he
waited for Camby&longs;es, in an Aqueduct made of
the Hides of Bulls, if we may believe every
thing that we read in Herodotus.

In the Coun­
try of the Samians, among other &longs;urprizing
Works, the mo&longs;t extraordinary of all was a
Trench &longs;eventy Furlongs in Length, made
through a Mountain which was an hundred
and fifty Paces high. Megareus's Conduct was
al&longs;o mightily admired, which brought the
Water of a Spring to the City in a Frame
twenty Foot high.

But in my Judgment the
ancient City of Rome far excelled all the Cities
in the World in the Grandeur and Contrivance
of her Aqueducts, and the great Plenty of
Water conveyed in them.

But you are not
every where &longs;ure to find Springs or Rivers from
whence Water can be brought. Alexander,
to &longs;upply his Fleet with Water, dug a Number
of Wells along the Sea Shore of Per&longs;ia.

Ap­
pian tells us, that Hannibal, when he was clo&longs;e

being able to find Water in the Field where he

Be&longs;ides, it is
not all Waters which you find, that are good
and proper for the U&longs;e of Men; for be&longs;ides
that, &longs;ome are hot, &longs;ome cold, &longs;ome &longs;weet,
&longs;ome &longs;harp, &longs;ome bitter, &longs;ome perfectly clear,
others muddy, vi&longs;cous, oily, tinctured with
Pitch, or of a petri&longs;ying Quality; &longs;ome run­
ning partly clear, and partly foul, and &longs;ome­

&longs;alt or bitter: There are al&longs;o &longs;everal other Par­
ticulars, well worth Note, which make Wa­
ters very different from one another, as well in

quence to the Pre&longs;ervation or Prejudice of the
Health.

And here let us be allowed ju&longs;t to
mention &longs;ome miraculous Properties of Water,
by Way of Amu&longs;ement.

The River Ar&longs;ione
in Armenia, rots the Cloaths which are wa&longs;h­
ed in it.

The Water of Diana's Fountain,
near Camerinum, will mix with nothing Male.

At Debri, a Town of the Garamanthes, is a
Spring which is cold in the Day, and warm in
the Night.

The Helbe&longs;us, a River in the Coun­
try of the Sege&longs;tani in Sicily, in the Middle of
its Cour&longs;e grows of a &longs;udden hot.

There is a
&longs;acred Well in Epirus, which extingui&longs;hes any
Thing which is put into it burning, and lights
that which is extingui&longs;hed.

In Eleu&longs;ina near
Athens, is a Spring which leaps and rejoices at
the Sound of a Flute.

Foreign Animals that
drink at the River Indus, change their Colour:
And upon the Shore of the Red Sea there is a
Spring, at which if Sheep drink, their Wool
pre&longs;ently turns Black.

At Laodicea in A&longs;ia,
there are Springs, near which all the fourfoot­
ed Animals that are conceived are of a yellow
Hue.

In the Country of Gadara, is a Water,
of which if the Cattle drink, they lo&longs;e their
Hair and Nails.

Near the Hyrcanian Sea, is a
Lake, wherein all that bathe grow &longs;cabby, and
can be cured with nothing but Oil.

At Su&longs;a,
is a Water which makes the Teeth fall out of
the Head.

Near the Lake Zelonium, is a Spring
which makes Women barren, and another
which makes them fruitful.

In the I&longs;land of
Chies, there is one which makes tho&longs;e that
drink of it fooli&longs;h: And in &longs;ome other Place,
which I do not now recollect, is one which
not only upon drinking, but upon the bare

And near Nonacris in Arca­
dia, is a Water perfectly clear to the View, but
of &longs;o poi&longs;onous a Quality, that it cannot be

On the
contrary, there are others which are admirable

But it is
yet more extraordinary which we are told of

&longs;olidate broken Bones, and prevent the Effect

In other Places
there are Waters which mend the Wit and even
in&longs;pire Divination.

In Cor&longs;ica, al&longs;o there is
another Spring very good for the Eyes, which

diately makes him blind.

Of the&longs;e we have
&longs;aid enough.

La&longs;tly, in &longs;ome Places no Wa­
ter at all is to be found, neither good nor bad.

To remedy this, it was the Cu&longs;tom all over the
