CHAP. III.

Four Things to be con&longs;idered with Relation to Water; al&longs;o whence it is engender­
ed or ari&longs;es, and its Cour&longs;e.

There are four Things therefore which
are to our Purpo&longs;e with Relation to
Water; namely, the finding, the conveying,
the chu&longs;ing, and the pre&longs;erving.

Of the&longs;e we
are to treat: But we may fir&longs;t premi&longs;e &longs;ome
few Things concerning the Nature of Water in
general.

I am of Opinion that Water cannot
be contained in any Thing but a Ve&longs;&longs;el, and
therefore I agree with tho&longs;e, who upon that
Account, affirm the Sea it&longs;elf to be nothing
but a Ve&longs;&longs;el of va&longs;t Capacity, and Rivers to be
great oblong Ve&longs;&longs;els too.

But there is this
Difference between the Waters of the Sea and
tho&longs;e of Rivers, that the&longs;e latter have a Cur­
rent and Motion by their own Nature, whereas
the former would ea&longs;ily &longs;ub&longs;ide and be at Re&longs;t,
if they were not put in Agitation by the Force of
the Winds.

I &longs;hall not here di&longs;cu&longs;s tho&longs;e philo­
&longs;ophical Que&longs;tions, whether all Waters make
their Way to the Sea, as to a Place of Re&longs;t, and
whether the regular Flux and Reflux of the
Ocean be owing to the Impul&longs;e of the Moon:
Tho&longs;e Points not being to our Purpo&longs;e: but
we mu&longs;t not omit to take Notice of what we
&longs;ee with our Eyes, that Water naturally tends
downwards; that it cannot &longs;uffer the Air to
be any where beneath it; that it hates all Mix­
ture with any Body that is either lighter or
heavier than it&longs;elf; that it loves to fill up every
Concavity into which it runs; that the more
you endeavour to force it, the more ob&longs;tinate­
ly it &longs;trives again&longs;t you, nor is ever &longs;atisfied till
it obtains the Re&longs;t which it de&longs;ires, and that
when it is got to its Place of Repo&longs;e, it is con­
tented only with it&longs;elf, and de&longs;pi&longs;es all other
Mixtures; la&longs;tly, that its Surface is always an
exact Level.

There is another Enquiry relat­
ing to Water, which I remember to have read
in Plutarch; namely, whether upon digging a
Hole in the Earth, the Water &longs;prings up like
Blood out of a Wound; or whether it di&longs;tills
out like Milk engendering by Degrees in the
Brea&longs;t of a Nur&longs;e.

Some are of Opinion, that
perpetual Springs do not run from any full
Ve&longs;&longs;el from whence they have their &longs;upply,
but that in the Places from whence they flow,
the Water is continually engendering of Air,
and not of all Sorts of Air, but only of &longs;uch as
is mo&longs;t apt to be formed into Vapour, and that
the Earth, and e&longs;pecially the Hills, are like
Spunges, full of Pores, through which the Air
is &longs;ucked in and conden&longs;ed and &longs;o turned into
Water by the Cold: For Proof of which they
alledge, that the greate&longs;t Rivers &longs;pring from
the greate&longs;t Hills.

Others do not agree with
this Opinion, ob&longs;erving that &longs;everal Rivers, and
particularly the Pyramus, one of no &longs;mall Note,
being navigable, does not take its Ri&longs;e from
any Hill, but from the Middle of a Plain.

For
this Rea&longs;on, he who &longs;uppo&longs;es that the Ground
imbibes the Moi&longs;ture of the Rain, which by
its Weight and Subtilty penetrates through the
Veins and &longs;o di&longs;tills into the Cavities of the
Earth, may perhaps be not much mi&longs;taken in
his Conjecture: For we may ob&longs;erve, that tho&longs;e
Countries which have lea&longs;t Rain, have the
greate&longs;t Scarcity of Springs. Libya is &longs;aid to
have been &longs;o called qua&longs;i Lipygia, as wanting
Rain, by which means it is &longs;cantily &longs;upplied
with Water.

And, indeed, who can deny,
that where it Rains much, there is the greate&longs;t
Plenty of it?

It is al&longs;o to our pre&longs;ent Purpo&longs;e
to ob&longs;erve, that a Man who digs a Well never
meets with Water, till he has &longs;unk it to the
Level of the next River.

At Vol&longs;conio, a Town
&longs;tanding upon a Hill in Tu&longs;cany, they dug a
Well no le&longs;s then two hundred and twenty
Foot deep before they came to any Vein of
Water, not meeting with any till they came
to the Level of the Springs which ri&longs;e from the
Side of the Hill; and you will generally find
the &longs;ame Ob&longs;ervation hold good of all Wells
dug upon Hills.

We find by Experiment that
a Spunge will grow wet by the Humidity of
the Air, upon which I have made a Pair of
Scales to determine the Heavine&longs;s or Dryne&longs;s
of the Air and Winds.

I cannot indeed deny
that the Moi&longs;ture of the nocturnal Air is at­
tracted from the Superficies of the Earth, and
&longs;o con&longs;equently may return again into its Pores,
and be ea&longs;ily converted once more into Hu­
mour; but I cannot pretend to determine any
thing certain with Relation to this Que&longs;tion,
finding &longs;o much Variety among Authors upon
the Subject, and &longs;o many different Con&longs;iderati­
ons offering them&longs;elves to the Mind when we
think upon it.

Thus it is certain that in many
Places, either by &longs;ome Earthquake, or even
from no apparent Cau&longs;e, Springs have bur&longs;t out
of a &longs;udden, and continued a great While, and
again, that others have failed in different Sea­
&longs;ons, &longs;ome growing dry in Summer, others in
Winter, and that tho&longs;e which have dried up
have afterwards again afforded great Plenty of
Water: Nay, and that Springs of fre&longs;h Wa­
ter not only ari&longs;e from the Earth, but have
been found even in the Middle of the Sea; and
it has been affirmed, that Water al&longs;o i&longs;&longs;ues from
the Plants them&longs;elves.

In one of tho&longs;e I&longs;lands
which are called Fortunate, we are told there
grows a Sort of Cane as high as a Tree, &longs;ome
black, &longs;ome white; from the black comes a
bitter Juice, and from the white di&longs;tills a fine
clear Water, very beautiful to the Eye and good
to drink. Strabo, a very grave Author, &longs;ays
that in the Mountains of Armenia, they find a
Sort of Worms bred in the Snow, which are
full of a Water excellent to drink.

At Fiezole
and Urbino, though both Towns &longs;tanding up­
on Hills, there is Plenty of Water to be had
for the lea&longs;t digging, which is becau&longs;e tho&longs;e
Hills are formed of a &longs;tony Soil mixed with a
Chalk.

We are told further, that there are
certain Clods of Earth which within their
Coats contain a Quantity of the fine&longs;t Water.

Amid&longs;t all this wonderful Variety, the Know­
ledge of the Nature of Springs cannot be other­
wi&longs;e than extremely difficult and ob&longs;cure.
CHAP. IV.
By what Marks to find any hidden Water.
Let us now return to our Subject.

Hid­
den Waters are to be found out by cer­
tain Marks.

The&longs;e Marks are the Form and
Face of the Spot of Ground, and the Nature
of the Soil where you are to &longs;earch for the
Water, and &longs;ome other Methods di&longs;covered by
the Indu&longs;try and Diligence of Men.

Accord­
ing to the ordinary Cour&longs;e of Nature, a Place
which is &longs;unk down into a Hollow, or into a
Sort of concave Pit, &longs;eems to be a Kind of Ve&longs;­
&longs;el ready prepared for the retaining of Water.

In tho&longs;e Places where the Sun has much Pow­
er, all Humidity is &longs;o much dried up by the
Force of his Rays, that few or no Veins of
Water are to be found; or if any are di&longs;co­
vered in a very open Place, they are heavy,
thick and bracki&longs;h.

On the north Side of
Hills, and where-ever there is a very thick
Shade, you may very &longs;oon meet with Water.

Hills who&longs;e Tops are u&longs;ed to be long covered
with Snow, afford great Plenty of Springs.

I
have ob&longs;erved, that Hills which have a flat
Meadow at the Top, never want Water; and
you will find almo&longs;t all Rivers have their Ri&longs;e
from &longs;ome &longs;uch Place.

I have al&longs;o ob&longs;erved,
that their Springs &longs;eldom flow from any other
Spot of Ground, but where the Soil beneath or
about them is &longs;ound and firm, with either an
even Slope over them, or &longs;oft loo&longs;e Earth: So
that if you con&longs;ider the Matter, you will be of
Opinion with me, that the Water which has
been gathered there, runs out as from the Side
of a broken Ba&longs;on.

Hence it happens that the
clo&longs;e&longs;t Soil has the lea&longs;t Water, and what there
is, lies very near the Surface: But the loo&longs;e&longs;t
Earth has the mo&longs;t Humidity; but then the
Water generally lies pretty deep. Pliny writes,
that in &longs;ome Places, upon cutting down the
Woods, Springs bur&longs;t out: And Tacitus &longs;ays,
that when Mo&longs;es journeyed through the De­
&longs;art, and his Followers were fainting with
Thir&longs;t, he di&longs;covered Springs of Water, only
by taking Notice where there were fre&longs;h Spots
of Gra&longs;s. Æmilius, when his Army &longs;uffered a
Dearth of Water near Mount Olympus, found
out a Supply by the fre&longs;h Verdure of the
Woods.

Some Soldiers who were in que&longs;t of
Water were directed to &longs;ome little Veins by a
young Girl in the Via Collatina, where, upon
digging they found a very plentiful Spring, over
which they built a little Chapel, and in it left
the Memory of the Accident de&longs;cribed in Paint­
ing.

If the Earth ea&longs;ily gives Way to the
Tread, or cleaves to the Foot, it &longs;hews that
there is Water under it.

One of the mo&longs;t cer­
tain Marks of concealed Water, is the Growth
and Flouri&longs;hing of tho&longs;e Plants which love
Water, or are u&longs;ed to be produced by it, &longs;uch
as Willows, Ru&longs;hes, Withes, Ivy, or any others
which without Plenty of Moi&longs;ture could never
have attained the Perfection in which we find
them. Columella tells us, that the Ground
which produces Vines very thick of Leaves,
and e&longs;pecially that which bears Dwar&longs;-elder,
Trefoil and wild Plumbs is a good Soil, and
does not want Veins of &longs;weet Water.

More­
over great Quantities of Frogs, Earth-worms,
with Gnats and other &longs;mall Flies &longs;warming
together in the Air, are Tokens of Water con­
cealed beneath.

The Methods for finding
Water invented by the Diligence of Men are
as follows: The curious Searchers into Nature
have ob&longs;erved, that the Earth, and e&longs;pecially
the Hills, con&longs;i&longs;t of different Coats or Layers,
&longs;ome clo&longs;er, &longs;ome loo&longs;er, and others thinner;
and they have found, that the Hills were com­
po&longs;ed of the&longs;e Coates placed one above the
other, in &longs;uch a Manner that towards the Sur­
face or out&longs;ide the&longs;e Layers or Coats, and their
&longs;everal Junctures lie level from the Right to
Left: But on the In&longs;ide, towards the Center
of the Hill the Layers incline downwards in an
oblique Line, with all their upper Superficies
inclining equally, but then the &longs;ame Line does
not continue on, quite to the Center of the
Hill, for, &longs;uppo&longs;e at the Di&longs;tance of every
hundred Foot the Line is broken off by a Kind
of tran&longs;ver&longs;e Step, which makes a Di&longs;continu­
ance in the Layer; and &longs;o with the&longs;e Breaks
and Slopes the Coats run from each Side to the
Center of the Hill.

From an Ob&longs;ervation of
the&longs;e Particulars, Men of acute Under&longs;tanding
&longs;oon perceived that the Waters were either en­
gendered, or rather that the Rains gathered
between the&longs;e Strata, and in the Junctures of
the &longs;everal Coats, by which means the Middle
of the Hill mu&longs;t needs have Water in it.

Hence they concluded that in order to come at
that conccaled Water, they mu&longs;t pierce into
the Body of the Hill, and e&longs;pecially in one of
tho&longs;e Parts where the Lines or Junctures of the
&longs;everal Strata met together, which was likely
to be the mo&longs;t proper Place for what they
wanted, becau&longs;e the Mu&longs;eles of the Hill meet­
ing together mu&longs;t in all Probability form a na­
tural Re&longs;ervoir.

Be&longs;ides the &longs;everal Coats
them&longs;elves &longs;eemed to be of different Natures,
&longs;ome likely to imbibe, others to retain the Wa­
ter.

Thus the reddi&longs;h Stone is hardly ever
without Water; but then it is apt to deceive
you, for it often runs out through the Veins
with which that Stone abounds.

The moi&longs;t and
living Flint which lies about the Roots of the
Hill, broken and very &longs;harp, &longs;oon affords Wa­
ter.

The light Soil too gives you an ea&longs;y Op­
portunity of finding Plenty of Water; but then
it is of a bad Savour.

But the Male-&longs;and and
the hard Grit are &longs;ure to afford the be&longs;t of
Water, and with the lea&longs;t Danger of being ex­
hau&longs;ted.

It is quite the contrary with Chalk,
which being too clo&longs;e, yields no Water; but
it is very good for retaining that which di&longs;tills
into it.

In common Sand we find but very
&longs;mall Veins, and tho&longs;e foul, and apt to have a
Sediment.

CHAP. VII.
Of the Method of conveying Water and accommodating it to the U&longs;es of Men.

Having found Water and approved
it to be good, the next Work is to convey
it artfully and accommodate it properly to the
U&longs;es of Men.

There are two Ways of convey­
ing Water, either by a Trench or Canal, or by
Pipes or Conduits.

In either of the&longs;e Methods,
the Water will not move, unle&longs;s the Place to
which you would convey it be lower than that
from which it is to be brought.

But then there
is this Difference, that the Water which is brought
by a Canal mu&longs;t de&longs;cend all the Way with a
continued Slope, whereas that which is conveyed
in Pipes may a&longs;cend in &longs;ome Part of the Way.
Of the&longs;e two Methods we are now to treat.

But fir&longs;t we mu&longs;t premi&longs;e &longs;ome Things for the
clearer Explication of our Subject.

The
Searchers into Nature tell us, that the Earth is
Spherical, tho' in many Places it ri&longs;es into
Hills, and in many others &longs;inks into Seas: but
in &longs;o va&longs;t a Globe this Roughne&longs;s is not per­
ceptible; as in an Egg, which tho' it is far
from being of a &longs;mooth Superficies, yet its lit­

Proportion to its whole Circumference, they
are &longs;carce ob&longs;erved. Erato&longs;thenes tells us, that
the Compa&longs;s of this great Globe is two hun­
dred and fifty two thou&longs;and Furlongs, or about
thirty one thou&longs;and five hundred Miles, and
that there is no Hill &longs;o high or Water &longs;o deep
as to be above fifteen thou&longs;and Cubits perpen­
dicular; not even Mount Cauca&longs;us, who&longs;e Top
enjoys the Sun three Hours in the Night.

There is a prodigious high Mountain in Ar­
cadia called Cyllene; and yet tho&longs;e who have
mea&longs;ured its perpendicular, affirm, that it does
not exceed twenty Furlongs.

Even the Sea it­
&longs;elf is thought to be no more upon this Globe
of Earth, than the Summer's Dew is upon the
Body of an Apple.

Some have wittily &longs;aid,
that the Creator of the World made u&longs;e of the
Concavity of the Sea as of a Seal with the Im­
pre&longs;&longs;ion whereof he &longs;tampt the Hills.

What
the Geometers teach us upon this Head is very
much to our pre&longs;ent Purpo&longs;e.

They &longs;ay, that
if a &longs;traight Line touching the Globe of the
Earth at one End were to be drawn on exactly
horizontal a Mile in Length, the Space be­
tween the other End and the Surface of the
Globe would not be above ten Inches.

For
this Rea&longs;on Water will never move on in a
Canal, but &longs;tand &longs;till like a Lake, unle&longs;s every
eight Furlongs the Trench has a Slope of one
whole Foot from the Place where the Water

the ancient Lawyers called Incile, from the In­
ci&longs;ion which is made either in the Rock or
Bank for conveying the Water: But if in this
Space of eight Furlongs it had a Slope of more
than &longs;ix Foot, it is &longs;uppo&longs;ed that the Rapidity
of its Current would make it inconvenient for
Boats.

In order to find whether the Trench
which is to convey the Water be lower than
this Incile or Sluice or no, and what the Slope
is, certain Rules and In&longs;truments have been
invented, which are of excellent U&longs;e.

Ignorant
Workmen try their Slope by laying a Ball in
the Trench, and if this Ball rowls forwards
they think the Slope is right for their Water.

The In&longs;truments of dexterous Arti&longs;ts are the
Square, Level, Plumb-line, and, in a Word, all
&longs;uch as are terminated with a right Angle.

This Art is a little more ab&longs;tru&longs;e; but how­
ever I &longs;hall open no more of it than is nece&longs;­
&longs;ary for the Purpo&longs;e in Hand.

The Practice
is performed by means of the Sight and of the
Object, which we &longs;hall call the Points.

If the
Place through which we are to convey our

directing our Sight: For we mu&longs;t &longs;et up cer­
tain Marks or Objects, which we may place
either nearer or at a greater Di&longs;tance from
each other.

The nearer the Points of the Sight
and the Mark or Object are to each other, the

Sight will depart from the Superficies of the
Globe; the further tho&longs;e Points are from each
other, the lower the Superficies of the Globe
will fall from the Level of the Sight.

In both
the&longs;e you mu&longs;t ob&longs;erve to allow ten Inches
&longs;lope for every Mile of Di&longs;tance.

But if you
have not a clear Plain, and &longs;ome Hill interferes,
then again you have two Ways of Proceeding:
One by taking the Height from the Incile or
Sluice, on the one Side, and the Height of the
Slope from the Head on the other.

The Head
I call that appointed Place to which you would
bring the Water, in order to let it run from

We find the&longs;e Heights by taking different

I call them Steps be­
cau&longs;e they are like tho&longs;e Steps by which we
a&longs;cend to a Temple.

One Line of the&longs;e Steps
is the Ray of Sight which goes from the Be­

falls from the Beholder's Eye down to his Feet,

By means of the&longs;e Steps

The other Method, is by drawing one

But this Method is di&longs;&longs;icult in

But there are &longs;ome Things which

The Prac­

&longs;cribe a Circle ten Foot in Diameter.

This
Circle we &longs;hall call the Horizon.

In the Cen­

Having made this Preparation, the

Having found out and marked this
exact Place in the Circumference of his Hori­

Thus this Line will be the Diameter of

If this Line, upon taking oppo&longs;ite Views

But if the two Lines of Di­

of that in another Place.

ones, and cement their Joints with Lime

Thus join the Ends of the Timber to­

When

&longs;trained and compre&longs;&longs;ed too clo&longs;e.

I have read

The Ar­
ti&longs;ts in Hydraulics can force Water to leap up

CHAP. VIII.
Of Ci&longs;terns, their U&longs;es and Conveniencies.
I now come to &longs;peak of Ci&longs;terns.

A Ci&longs;tern
is a large Ve&longs;&longs;el for holding Water, not

Its
Bottom and Sides therefore mu&longs;t be perfectly
&longs;trong and well compacted.

There are two
Sorts, one for containing Water for Drinking,
and the other for pre&longs;erving it for other U&longs;es,
as particularly again&longs;t &longs;udden Fires.

The fir&longs;t
we &longs;hall call a Drinking-ci&longs;tern, the other a

The Drinking-ci&longs;tern out to pre­
&longs;erve its Water in the greate&longs;t Purity; becau&longs;e
when it is impure it is the Cau&longs;e of a great many

In both we are to take care
that the Water is properly admitted, pre&longs;erved
and di&longs;pen&longs;ed.

Water is brought into the Ci&longs;­
tern by Pipes from the River or Spring, and
&longs;ometimes Rain-water from the Hou&longs;e-top or
from the Ground.

I was extremely plea&longs;ed
with the Invention of an Architect, who in a
large bare Rock on the Summit of a Hill cut
a round Ba&longs;on ten Foot deep, which received
all the Rain-water which ran into it from that
naked Rock.

Then in the Plain under the
Hill he erected a Water-hou&longs;e, open on every
Side, and built of Brick and Mortar, thirty
Foot high, forty long and forty broad.

Into
this Water-hou&longs;e he brought the Rain-water
from the upper Re&longs;ervoir by a &longs;ubterraneous

much higher than the Top of the Water-hou&longs;e.

If you &longs;trew the Bottom of your Ci&longs;tern with
good round Pebbles, or large Gravel from the

will make your Water clear, cool and pure;
and the Higher you make this Strewing, your
Water will be the more limpid.

The Water
&longs;ometimes runs out at the Joints and Cracks
of the Ci&longs;tern if it is ill made; and &longs;ometimes
the Water is &longs;poiled by Filth.

And indeed it
is no ea&longs;y Matter to keep Water impri&longs;oned,
unle&longs;s the Re&longs;ervoir be &longs;trongly built, and even
of good &longs;quare Stone.

It is al&longs;o particularly
nece&longs;&longs;ary, that the Work &longs;hould be perfectly
dry before you let the Water into it, which
pre&longs;&longs;ing hard upon it with its Weight, and
Sweating through it by means of its Humidi­
ty, if it can but make a &longs;mall Crack, will be
continually working its Way till it has opened
it&longs;elf a large Pa&longs;&longs;age.

The Ancients guarded
again&longs;t this Inconvenience, and e&longs;pecially in

tations of Marbles.

But nothing better pre­
vents this oozing out of the Water, than Chalk

tern and the Side of the Trench in which it is
made.

We order the Chalk which we u&longs;e for
this Purpo&longs;e to be thoroughly dried and beat
into Powder.

Some think, that if you fill a
Gla&longs;s Ve&longs;&longs;el with Salt, and &longs;top it up clo&longs;e
with a Plai&longs;ter of Mortar tempered with Oil,
that no Water may get in, and then hang it

vent the Water from corrupting, let it be kept

Some add Quick-&longs;ilver to the
Compo&longs;ition.

Others &longs;ay, that if you take a
new earthen Ve&longs;&longs;el full of &longs;harp Vinegar, &longs;topt

They tell us too,

We are told of an old
Saying of Epigenes, that Water which has been
once corrupted, will in Time recover and pu­

Water which is beginning to corrupt, if it is
&longs;tirred about, and poured often out of one Ve&longs;­
&longs;el into another, will lo&longs;e its ill Smell, which

It is certain that Water

bitter, by throwing Barley-flower into it may

But in order to refine the Wa­

ed with its own proper Wall, and its Bottom a
&longs;mall matter lower than the Bottom of the Ci&longs;­

This Well on the Side next the Ci&longs;tern

In the Territory
of Tarragona in Spain, is found a white Pu­

e&longs;t Clearne&longs;s.

It will al&longs;o come out extreme­
ly limpid if you fill up the Aperture, through

At Bologna,
they have a &longs;oft &longs;andy Stone of a yellow Colour,

Drop till it is wonderfully refined.

Some
make Bread of Sea-water; than which nothing
can be more unwhole&longs;ome.

But yet tho&longs;e
Strainers which we have mentioned are &longs;o ef­

If you &longs;ink

Nor is it fo­

When

When the Current of the Water has

Of planting a Vineyard in a Meadow, or a Wood in a Mar&longs;h; and how we
may amend a Region which is mole&longs;ted with too much Water.
I now proceed to other Conveniencies.

We
ob&longs;erved that Food and Rayment was to
provided for the Inhabitants.

With the&longs;e we
are to be &longs;upplied by Agriculture, an Art

Yet there are &longs;ome Ca&longs;es wherein the Archi­

As particularly when a Piece of Ground being

A Vineyard may be

On the contrary, upon a dry

Into this Trench bring

Afterwards if you bring
down &longs;ome Land-flood upon it, which may
&longs;ub&longs;ide there, it will make a Cru&longs;t over the

But of this in another Place.

If the
Region is &longs;ubject to Inundations, as Lombardy

&longs;ome either from its over-abundance, or from

Upon the&longs;e

The

CHAP. X.
Of Roads; of Pa&longs;&longs;ages by Water, and of artificial Banks to Rivers.

The next Bu&longs;ine&longs;s is to get as conveni­
ently as is po&longs;&longs;ible from abroad, tho&longs;e
Nece&longs;&longs;aries which we cannot be &longs;upplied with
at home.

To this Purpo&longs;e are Roads and
Highways, which are to be made &longs;uch, that
whatever is wanting may be ea&longs;ily brought, in
its proper Sea&longs;on.

There are two Sorts of
Highways, one by Land, the other by Water,
as we hinted in the formar Part of this Work.

Care is to be taken that the Highway by Land
is not too deep, nor too much broke by Car­
riages; and be&longs;ides tho&longs;e Cau&longs;eways which we
have &longs;poken of formerly, we &longs;hould be &longs;ure to
let them be open to a good deal of Sun and to
a free Air, and that they be not covered with
too much Shade.

In our Days, near the Wood
by Ravenna, the Road which u&longs;ed to be very
bad, has been made extremely convenient by
cutting down the Trees, and admitting the
Sun to it.

We may generally ob&longs;erve little
Puddles under Trees which &longs;tand by the Side
of the Road, occa&longs;ioned by the Tread of Cat­
tle, and the Shade preventing the Ground
from drying &longs;o fa&longs;t as it otherwi&longs;e would do,
&longs;o that the Rain always &longs;ettles and lies there.

Highways (if we may &longs;o call them) by Water
are of two Sorts: One which may be corrected
and forced; as Rivers or Canals; the other
which cannot; as the Sea.

We may venture
to &longs;ay, that there happen the &longs;ame Faults in a
River as we find in a &longs;maller Ve&longs;&longs;el for con­
taining Water; that is, that perhaps either the
Sides, or the Bottom are defective or not &longs;ound
and convenient.

For as a large Quantity of
Water is nece&longs;&longs;ary for the carrying of Ships, if
it is not contained in &longs;tout Banks, it may break
its Way through them and drown all the Coun­
try, and &longs;o even &longs;poil the Highways on Shore.

If the Bottom be very &longs;teep, how can we ima­
gine that a Ship can make its Way up again&longs;t
the Rapidity of the Stream?

and if it ri&longs;es in­
to Shelves, it will &longs;poil the Navigation.

Upon
bringing the famous Obelisk from Ægypt to
Rome, it was found that the Tyber was a more
convenient River for Navigation than the Nile.
The latter indeed was much broader, but the
former was of a more convenient Depth: For
it is not &longs;o much a great Plenty as a good Depth
of Water that is nece&longs;&longs;ary for Navigation.

Though a hand&longs;ome Breadth is very conveni­
ent too, becau&longs;e by that means the Streams
comes &longs;lower again&longs;t the Banks.

A River
that has not a &longs;ound Bottom, will &longs;carce
have &longs;trong Banks; and &longs;carce any Bottom
can be called &longs;ound, which has not &longs;uch a
Strength as we have formerly required in the
Foundations of Buildings, namely, to be &longs;o &longs;olid
as in a Manner to defy even Tools of Iron.

Thus the Bottom will be uncertain if the Banks
are chalky, or if the River runs along a flat
Plain, or if the Soil is covered with loo&longs;e round
Stones.

When the Banks of a River are un­
firm, its Channel will be &longs;topt up with Shelves,
Ruins, broken Trunks of Trees, and &longs;oft
Stones.

The weake&longs;t Sides of all, and the mo&longs;t
variable, are tho&longs;e thrown up by &longs;ome &longs;udden
Inundation.

From this Weakne&longs;s of the Sides
follows what is &longs;aid of the Meander and the
Euphrates, the former of which we are told,
u&longs;ed ea&longs;ily to cut through his &longs;oft Banks and
be daily running into new Windings, and the
Euphrates on the other Hand was continually
&longs;topping up the Canals, through which he was
conveyed, with the Ruins of his Shore.

The&longs;e
Defects in the natural Banks the Ancients u&longs;ed
to remedy with artificial ones; the Rules for
which are much the &longs;ame with tho&longs;e for
other Kinds of Structures; for we are to con­
&longs;ider well with what Lines we erect it, and with
what Kind of Work.

If the artificial Bank is
built in a parallel Line with the Current of the
River, the Force of the Stream will never bear
again&longs;t it: But if it is built &longs;o as to &longs;tand
again&longs;t the Current, if it is not very &longs;trong it
will be overthrown by it; or if it be too low
the Water will overflow it.

If &longs;uch a Bank be
not overthrown, it will be continually growing
higher and higher at the Bottom, becau&longs;e there
every Thing which the Stream brings along
with it will &longs;top, till at la&longs;t having made a Hill
again&longs;t it which it can remove no further, it
will be apt to turn its Cour&longs;e another Way.

If
the Force of the Water throws down the Bank,
then it will have tho&longs;e Effects natural to it,
which we ob&longs;erved before, by filling all the
Hollows, driving out the Air, and &longs;weeping
away every Thing that it meets in its Pa&longs;&longs;age:
But &longs;till leaving behind it by Degrees as it
&longs;lackens the Violence of its own Cour&longs;e, &longs;uch
heavy Things as are not ea&longs;ily carried far.

Thus in the Mouth of the Breach which the
River makes in its Banks, the Inundation will
leave a Shelf of coar&longs;e Sand of a con&longs;iderable
Height; but as it goes further it will only co­
ver the Ground with a &longs;mall Slime.

If the
River does not immediately break down its
Bank, but only overflows the Top of it,
the Violence with which it falls upon the
Ground on the other Side of it will wa&longs;h away
the Earth, till by Degrees it undermines and
brings down the whole Bank it&longs;elf.

If the Cur­
rent neither is parallel with the Bank, nor &longs;ets
again&longs;t it directly, but only &longs;trikes it oblique­
ly, it will bear no le&longs;s, in Proportion to the
Angle of its Obliquity, again&longs;t the Sides to
which it is thrown off, than again&longs;t that which
it meets with fir&longs;t.

And indeed this Flexion
will give it &longs;omewhat of the Nature of a Bank
that fronts the Current directly; &longs;o that it will
be liable to the very &longs;ame Injuries as the latter.

Thus the Bank will be wa&longs;hed away &longs;o much
the &longs;ooner, as the Eddies of the Water will be
more vehement and furious, foaming, and in a
Manner boiling with Violence: For the&longs;e
Whirls and Eddies in a River &longs;eem to have
&longs;omewhat of the Nature and Force of a Screw,
which no Strength or Solidity can long re&longs;i&longs;t.

We may ob&longs;erve as well under Stone Bridges,

Water; as in tho&longs;e Part of the River where after
having been &longs;ome Time confined within nar­
rower Banks, it finds a broader Channel to ex­
tend it&longs;elf in, with what Fury it breaks out,
rowling into Variety of Eddies, and tearing
away every Thing that it meets with, either
from the Banks or from the Bottom.

I dare
venture to affirm, that Hadrian's Bridge at
Rome, is one of the &longs;toute&longs;t Pieces of Work
that perhaps ever was performed; and yet the
Fury of the Water has &longs;o decay'd it, that I

every Year load its Piers with Boughs and
Trunks of Trees which they bring down
along with them, and in a great Mea&longs;ure &longs;top
up the Arches.

This makes the Water ri&longs;e &longs;till
higher, and then it falls down percipitately in­
to wild Eddies, which undermine the Back of
the Piers and endanger the whole Structure.

Thus much of the Banks: Let us now &longs;ay
&longs;omething of the Bottom of the River. He­
rodotus relates, that Nitocris, King of the A&longs;&longs;y­
rians, &longs;lackened the Cour&longs;e of the River Eu­
phrates near Me&longs;opotamia, which before was
too impetuous, by making its Channel wind
about more than it u&longs;ed to do.

It is al&longs;o rea­
&longs;onable to &longs;uppo&longs;e that the Water which has
the &longs;lowe&longs;t Current will be the mo&longs;t la&longs;ting:
Which may be &longs;omewhat illu&longs;trated by the
Compari&longs;on of a Man that de&longs;cends from a
&longs;teep Hill, and who comes down not direct
and as fa&longs;t as he can, but fetching different
Compa&longs;&longs;es about the Sides, &longs;ometimes to the
right Hand, and &longs;ometimes to the Left.

The
Rapidity of the Stream proceeds from the Steep­
ne&longs;s of the Channel.

A Current either too
&longs;wift or too &longs;low, is inconvenient.

The for­
mer demoli&longs;hes the Banks; the latter produ­
ces Weeds, and is ea&longs;ily frozen.

Making the
River narrower may perhaps force the Water
to ri&longs;e higher, and another Way to make it
deeper is digging the Channel, lower.

Deep­
ening the Channel, removing Impediments,
and clearing the River are all done by the
&longs;ame Methods and for the &longs;ame Purpo&longs;es,
whereof we &longs;hall &longs;peak pre&longs;ently: But deepen­
ing the Bottom of a River will be in vain, un­
le&longs;s we go on to do it quite away to the Sea,
in order to give the Stream its due Slope all

CHAP. XI.

Of Canals; how they are to be kept well &longs;upplied with Water, and the U&longs;es
of them not ob&longs;tructed.
We now proceed to &longs;peak of Canals.

Where it is ne­

Of the Sea Wall; of &longs;trengthening the Port; and of Locks for confining the

The Sea-&longs;hore al&longs;o is to be fortified with

We are told, that the Sea in its own

At Con&longs;tantinople it has no

But as upon almo&longs;t all Shores

I have &longs;aid el&longs;ewhere, that Sand is form'd of

BUT to return.

The Waves have this par­

Re&longs;olve to conquer or be o'ercome,

The next Point is how

When

Go on in the &longs;ame Manner to fill

But I

At Genoa there was a Rock lying un­

&longs;aid, that this Man u&longs;ed to &longs;tay under Water

From the&longs;e Principles many other

And thus much may &longs;uffice for cleaning

The Locks in a River are made

For either of
the&longs;e the Sides mu&longs;t be made full as &longs;trong as

which you are going to join to the other, and
to be in the Nature of Bands between the two
Walls; and your Wall in this Ca&longs;e &longs;hould al­
ways be built of &longs;quare Stone.

You may for­
tify an old Wall with a new Pila&longs;ter, in the
following Manner.

Fir&longs;t mark out its future
Breadth upon the Wall with red Oker.

Then
open a Break in the Bottom of the Wall quite
down below the Foundation, in Breadth &longs;ome
&longs;mall Matter more than your Pila&longs;ter, but not
very high.

Then immediately fill up this Break
with &longs;quare Stone worked together &longs;trong and
even.

By this Means that Part of the Wall
which is between the red Marks will be &longs;hored
up by the Thickne&longs;s of the Pila&longs;ter, and &longs;o the
whole will be made &longs;tronger.

Then in the
&longs;ame Manner that you have laid the Bottom of
this Pila&longs;ter you mu&longs;t go on to work up the
Body of it quite to the Top.

Thus much of
a Wall that is too thin.

Where the Wall has
not made good Bond, we mu&longs;t u&longs;e Cramps or
Spars of Iron, or rather of Bra&longs;s; but you
mu&longs;t take great Care that you do not weaken
the Ribs by boring the Holes from them.

If
the Weight of any crumbling Earth pu&longs;hes
again&longs;t &longs;ome Part of the Wall, and threatens
Injury to it by its Humidity, dig a Trench
along the Wall as broad as you find it nece&longs;­
&longs;ary, and in this Trench build &longs;ome Arches to
&longs;upport the Weight of the Earth which is
falling in, with a Current or Drain through
the&longs;e Arches for the Humidity to purge off
by; ot el&longs;e lay &longs;ome Girders along the Ground
with the Heads &longs;etting again&longs;t the Wall which
is &longs;hoved out by the Weight of the Earth, and
let the Heads of the&longs;e Girders into Summers,
which you may cover over with new Earth.

This will &longs;trengthen the Foundation, becau&longs;e
this new Earth will con&longs;olidate, and grow
compact, before the Strength of the Girders
will give Way.
CHAP. XVII.

Of &longs;ome Defects which cannot be provided again&longs;t, but which may be repaired
after they have happened.

I now proceed to tho&longs;e Defects which can­
not be fore&longs;een, but which when they have
happened may be repaired.

Cracks in the
Wall and Inclination from the Perpendicular,
are &longs;ometimes occa&longs;ioned by the Arches over it,
which pu&longs;h out the Wall, or becau&longs;e it is not
&longs;ufficiently &longs;trong to bear the Weight which is
laid upon it.

But the greate&longs;t Defects of this
Sort almo&longs;t con&longs;tantly proceed from &longs;ome Faults
in the Foundation; however we may ea&longs;ily
di&longs;cover whether they are from thence, or from
&longs;ome other Cau&longs;e by certain Symptoms.

Thus
to begin with Cracks in the Wall; to which &longs;o­
ever Side the Crack runs in its A&longs;cent, on that
Side you may be &longs;ure the Cau&longs;e of the Defect
lies &longs;omewhere in the Foundation.

If it does
not verge to either Side, but runs up in a direct
Line, and grows wider at the Top, then let us
take a careful View of the Cour&longs;es of Stone­
work on each Side; for on which ever Side
they &longs;ink from their Level, on that Side we
may be &longs;ure the Foundation has failed.

But
if the upper Part of the Wall is entire, and
there are Cracks in &longs;everal Places towards the
Bottom, which in their A&longs;cent run together
clo&longs;e at Top; then we may be &longs;atisfied that
the Corners of the Building &longs;tand firm, and
that the Defect is &longs;omewhere about the Mid­
dle in the Foundation.

If there is but one
Crack of this Sort, the higher up it goes, the
the more it &longs;hews the Corners to have given
Way.

In order to &longs;trengthen the Foundations
in any of the&longs;e Ca&longs;es, according to the Magni­
tude of the Structure and the Solidity of the
Ground, dig a narrow Pit near the Wall, but
&longs;o deep as to come to a firm Soil, and there
breaking through the Bottom of the Wall,
immediately work up to it with &longs;quare Stone,
and then leave it to &longs;ettle.

When that is &longs;et­
tled, dig another Pit in another Part, and un­
derprop it in the &longs;ame Manner, and in the &longs;ame
Manner give it Time to &longs;ettle.

By this Means
you will make a Kind of new Foundation to
the whole Wall.

But if even by digging you
cannot come at any firm Ground, then make
Holes in certain Places not too near the Cor­
ners, but pretty clo&longs;e to the Foundation of the
Wall, on both Sides, that is to &longs;ay, as well un­
der the Roof as under the open Air, and into
tho&longs;e Holes drive Piles as clo&longs;e as they will &longs;tick,
and over them lay the &longs;toute&longs;t Summers you
can get lengthways, with the Sides of the Wall.

Then acro&longs;s the&longs;e Summers lay the &longs;tronge&longs;t
Girders running under the Bottom of the
Foundation, which mu&longs;t re&longs;t with their whole
Weight upon the&longs;e Girders, as it were upon a
Bridge.

In all the&longs;e Reparations great Care
mu&longs;t be taken that no Part of the new Work
be too weak to &longs;upport the Weight which is to
bear upon it, and that for ever &longs;o long
Time: becau&longs;e the whole Pile bearing towards
that weaker Part, would immediately fall to
Ruins.

But where the Foundation has given
Way &longs;omewhere about the Middle of the Wall,
and the upper Part does not appear to be af­
fected by the Crack, then upon the Face of
the Wall mark out with your Oker an Arch
as large as the Ca&longs;e requires, or, in other Words,
&longs;o big as to take in all that Part of the Wall
which is &longs;unk.

Then beginning at one End
of this Arch, break into the Wall with an
Opening not bigger than one Stone of your in­
tended Arch will fill up; which Stones in an
Arch we formerly called Wedges, and im­
mediately in&longs;ert one of the&longs;e Wedges in &longs;uch a
Manner that its Lines may exactly an&longs;wer to
the Center to which you have de&longs;cribed your
Arch.

Then make another Break clo&longs;e above
it, and fill it up with another &longs;uch Wedge;
and &longs;o continuing the Work &longs;ucce&longs;&longs;ively,
compleat your whole Arch: and thus you
may fortify you Wall without Danger.

If a
Column or any other of the Ribs of the Building
is weakened, you may re&longs;tore it in the following
Manner.

Underprop the Architrave with a
&longs;trong Arch of Tile and Plai&longs;ter beat together,
as al&longs;o with Piers of Plai&longs;ter rais'd for this
Purpo&longs;e, in &longs;uch a Manner that this new Arch
may quite fill up the old Intercolumnation, or
Aperture between the Ribs: and let this un­
derproping be run up as fa&longs;t as po&longs;&longs;ible, and
without the lea&longs;t Intermi&longs;&longs;ion.

It is the Nature
of Plai&longs;ter to &longs;well as it dries: &longs;o that this new
Work, though quite fre&longs;h, will be able to take
upon it&longs;elf and &longs;u&longs;tain the Weight of the old
Wall Vault.

Then, having before got ready
all your Materials, take out the defective
Column, and &longs;upply its Place with a &longs;ound
one.

If you chu&longs;e rather to re&longs;t the old Wall
upon Timbers, then under&longs;hore it with Levers
made of &longs;trong Beams, and load the longer
Ends of tho&longs;e Levers with Baskets filled with
Sand, which will rai&longs;e up the Weight by de­
grees equally and without any Shocks.

If the
Wall is &longs;werved from its Perpendicular, fix
Planks or Timbers upright again&longs;t it, and
again&longs;t each of the&longs;e &longs;et a &longs;trong Timber by
Way of Shore, with its Foot &longs;tretching at &longs;ome
Di&longs;tance from the Wall.

Then either with
Levers or with Wedges, drive forwards the Feet
of the Shores by degrees, &longs;o as they may pre&longs;s
again&longs;t the Wall, and &longs;o by di&longs;tributing this
Force equally in all Parts, you will rai&longs;e the
Wall again to its perpendicular.

If this
cannot be done, prop it up with Shores of
Timber fixed well in the Ground, with their
Ends well daubed over with Pitch and Oil to
prevent their being corroded by the Touch of
Mortar; then erect Buttre&longs;&longs;es of &longs;quare Stone,
built &longs;o as to enclo&longs;e tho&longs;e Shores of Timber.
Perhaps a Colo&longs;&longs;us or &longs;ome &longs;mall Church is
&longs;unk to one Side in its whole Foundation.

In
this Ca&longs;e, you mu&longs;t either rai&longs;e that Part which
is &longs;unk, or take away that Part which is too
high; both very bold Attempts.

The fir&longs;t
Thing you are to do, is to bind and fa&longs;ten to­
gether, as &longs;trongly as po&longs;&longs;ible, the Foundation
and tho&longs;e Parts which will be in Danger of
being &longs;eparated by Motion, with good Timbers
and the &longs;tronge&longs;t Braces.

There are no bet­
ter Sort of Braces than &longs;trong Hoops of Iron
with Wedges drove in between them to keep
them tight.

Then we rai&longs;e up the Side of the
Wall which is &longs;unk with &longs;trong Timbers put
under it a&longs;ter the Manner of Levers, as above.

If you would rather rectify the Fault by taking
away from the Side which is too high, you
may do it in the following Manner: Dig away
the Ground about the Middle of that Side
quite below the Foundation, in the Bottom of
which you mu&longs;t there open a Break, not very
wide, but high enough for you to make it good
with &longs;trong &longs;quare Stone.

In making good
this Break you mu&longs;t not work it up quite to
the re&longs;t of the Building, but leave &longs;ome Inches
&longs;pace between the new Work and the Old;
and this Space you mu&longs;t fill up with Wedges
of the toughe&longs;t Oak drove in at very &longs;mall Di&longs;­
tances from each other.

In this Manner you
mu&longs;t go on to &longs;hore up all that Side which you
want to let down lower.

When the whole
Weight is thus &longs;upported, knock out the
Wedges by degrees, as gently and cautiou&longs;ly as
po&longs;&longs;ible, till the Wall is &longs;unk to its ju&longs;t Perpen­
dicular.

Then fill up the Spaces between the
Wedges which are left, with other Wedges of
the &longs;tronge&longs;t Stone that can be got.

In the
great Ba&longs;ilique of St. Peter at Rome, &longs;ome Parts
of the Wall which were over the Columns
being &longs;werved from their Uprights, &longs;o as to
threaten even the Fall of the whole Roof; I
contrived how the Defect might be remedied
as follows.

Every one of tho&longs;e Parts of the
Wall which had given Way, let it re&longs;t upon
what Column it would, I determined &longs;hould
be taken clear out, and made good again with
&longs;quare Stone which &longs;hould be worked true to
its Perpendicular, only leaving in the old Wall
&longs;trong Catches of Stone to unite the additional
Work to the former.

La&longs;tly, I would have
&longs;upported the Beam under which tho&longs;e uneven
Parts of the Wall were to be taken out, by
means of Engines, called Capra's, erected
upon the Roof, &longs;etting the Feet of tho&longs;e En­
gines upon the &longs;tronge&longs;t Parts of the Roof and
of the Wall.

This I would have done at dif­
ferent Times over the &longs;everal Columns where
the&longs;e Defects appear.

The Capra is a naval
Engine con&longs;i&longs;ting of three Timbers, the Heads
of which meet and are &longs;trongly braced or
bound together, and the Feet &longs;tretch out to a
Triangle.

This Engine, with the Addition of
Pullies and a Cap&longs;tern is very u&longs;eful for rai&longs;ing
great Weights.

If you are to lay a new Coat
over an old Wall or an old plai&longs;tered Floor, firft
wa&longs;h it well with clean Water, and then with
a Bru&longs;h whiten it over with Whiting di&longs;&longs;olved
and mixed with marble Du&longs;t; and this will
prepare it for holding the new Coat of Plai&longs;ter
or Stuc.

If a Pavement which is expo&longs;ed to
the open Air has any Cracks in it, you may
&longs;top them up with A&longs;hes &longs;ifted fine, and tem­
pered Oil, e&longs;pecially of Lin&longs;eed.

But the be&longs;t
Material for this Sort of Reparation is Chalk
mixed with quick Lime well beat together and
thoroughly burnt in the Kiln, and then &longs;laked
immediately with Oil; taking Care before you
fill up the Cracks with it to clean them from
all manner of Du&longs;t, which you may do with
Feathers, or by blowing it out with Bellows.

Nor let us under this Article of Amendments,
quite forget all Ornament.

If any Wall looks
unhand&longs;ome from being too high, embelli&longs;h it
either by fa&longs;tening on a Cornice of Stuc-work,
or by Painting it like Pannels, in order to divide
its Height into more decent Proportions.

If
a Wall be too long, adorn it with Columns
reaching from the Top to the Bottom, not &longs;et
too clo&longs;e to each other, which will be a kind of
Re&longs;ting-places to the Eye, and make the ex­
ce&longs;&longs;ive Length appear le&longs;s offen&longs;ive.

There is
another Thing not foreign to our pre&longs;ent Pur­
po&longs;e.

Many Parts of a Building, from being
either placed too low or encompa&longs;&longs;ed with
Walls not high enough, &longs;eem le&longs;s, and more
contracted than they really are; whereas when
they are either rai&longs;ed upon a higher Platfom,
or have &longs;ome Addition made to the Height of
their Walls, they &longs;eem at a Di&longs;tance much
larger than they did before.

It is al&longs;o certain,
that a hand&longs;ome Di&longs;po&longs;ition of the Apertures,
and placing the Door and Windows gracefully,
gives all the Aparments a greater Share both
of Dignity and Elegance than is to be imagined.
